output: Mr. President, first of all, I would like to congratulate Mr. Siebeck on the work done, because his report covers many of the concerns expressed in this.
The House is discussing these crucial problems for the entire European Union. These are water scarcity and drought, issues that have ceased to be only a problem of the countries of southern Europe.

I am glad that this project incorporates some of the reflections made in the opinion report for which I was rapporteur in the Committee on Agriculture in favor of agricultural activity, highlighting, for example, the role that farmers play in the sustainable management of available resources.

It also includes a reference to drought and water scarcity as factors that aggravate the prices of raw materials, an aspect that I think is very important to point out in these times, so that we keep in mind not only the environmental dimension of this problem, but also some of its most relevant economic consequences.

The Environment Committee also included the idea of creating a European drought observatory, an action that is also mentioned in the report of the Agriculture Committee and which I hope will one day be reflected in concrete facts.

The text that will be put to the vote tomorrow does not include, however, a proposal made by the Agriculture Committee to study the implementation of an economic adaptation fund against drought, a fund that would benefit all economic sectors, including agriculture.

For my part, I would like to make it clear that I will continue to defend the establishment of this fund, an idea that I will propose to Parliament again when the communication that the Commission plans to publish on adaptation to climate change arrives in the coming months.

I think that after the Solidarity Fund was established, which was created at the time to alleviate the losses caused by climate disasters, it is time for us to think of an instrument that acts a priori and is intended to finance preventive measures to reduce the environmental and economic cost of these climate disasters.
Atlético de Madrid, fans, and even the Spanish police are being mistreated by the European Football Federation.
But the case transcends the particular, because those federal bodies aggravate the sanctions for those who resort to ordinary justice.
This medieval conception, this funnel law, is incompatible with the law, with the European institutions from which we must react.
And we will end up doing it, because those medieval gentlemen, arbitrary with a fork and a knife, must be in line with the respect for the law and the ordinary procedural guarantees of our Europe.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, terrorism is a global phenomenon, and the actions of serious organized crime are also, and therefore the means must be proportional and must be fought effectively.

I have taken good note of the answers you have given to the questions, which were timely. It is true that guarantees must be demanded, it is true that it is a delicate issue, but it is no less true that it is absolutely inexcusable to set up, to form a globalized and harmonized response.
For some, terrorism is a bit too far-reaching and they are more concerned about individual guarantees.
I am concerned about individuals and collectives, and it is absolutely necessary that we start wherever we can.
If we have started with air transport, where companies already have that data, let's start there.

Let's demand guarantees, let's see what the scope of application is, let's start with international transport relations, and be careful, we will have to continue with domestic transport, because terrorists often do not come from outside, but from within.
Ask the United States and ask others that this is the case and that we will have to raise it.
Mr. President, I would like to thank the Commission for presenting this proposal.
I think it is a positive proposal and will help us reduce unnecessary administrative burdens.
Now, as the speakers who have preceded me have said, this Parliament has the obligation to bring to the ground what are very generous and very altruistic proposals on the part of the Commission.

And the reality is that there is a national reality in which there are 27 countries with different legal systems and very different languages, which requires that in each of those countries we adjust to the realities of the country, including the issue of languages.

Specifically, as Gosset has pointed out right now and as previous speakers have pointed out, it is important that the recognition of these national specialties does not lead to an increase in costs, that the rates are uniform and that governments eventually assume that additional cost.
But there is also a topic that appears, and that is the topic of translations.
Specifically, in the European Union we do not have a common language.
In the 27 countries, very different languages are spoken among them. Even in some countries, like the Commissioner's, different languages are spoken and we live with this.
And from a legal point of view, we also find that legal documents are different.
The Legal Commission has proposed, for example, amendments on the authentication of the minutes of the documents, along with the authentication of the translation.
At this moment, the Committee on Legal Affairs is preparing a report on the recognition of authentic documents in different countries of the European Union that should complement this report.
In short, I believe the Commission has done well by presenting this report.

The rapporteur has done a magnificent job and I believe we have all made an effort to make a legislative text proposal that can be recognized throughout the Union, guaranteeing the rights of citizens.
rights and starting from the foundations of the reality of a union that is being built, which has different national systems and different levels of access to electronic communication.

Mr. President, a large majority of farmers and ranchers are waiting for the decisions and prior agreements that the Council of Agriculture Ministers of the Union will adopt between today and tomorrow on this check of the.
The CAP, because it is not just a revision, but it will bring profound changes, such as the disappearance of many farms, if this cut proposed by the European Commission on direct aid goes ahead.

Modulation is the central point of this parliamentary report and could be one of the few elements of the Parliament's opinion with any impact on the negotiations that the Union's agriculture ministers are conducting.
We have been opposed for years to any increase in what we euphemistically call modulation, because if the rural development policy does not have sufficient funds, it is not.
It is not due to a lack of resources within the CAP expenditure ceiling, but due to an absolute lack of political will to provide the Community budget with that necessary pillar development.
Do you want to liberalize the markets?
Of course, do it, but with equal requirements and conditions for all producers, both within and outside the Union.

At the moment, the European Union is playing with the future of many farmers and livestock breeders, and I would like to refer in particular to fragile sectors such as sheep, beef or tobacco, whose survival in many producing areas will depend on this check.

Some producers, such as sheep producers, no longer ask for help, but simply want to be allowed to leave the market with dignity, because they have made calculations and the only way to survive is to reduce the volumes produced.

The abandonment of production, therefore, is the only way out for many producers, whose space will undoubtedly be occupied by imports from third countries, because the consumer will not stop consuming and the world will not stop increasing the number of consumers at a tremendous pace.
The Parliament should issue a prudent opinion and the Council should listen to it.

I would like to thank the President of the Agriculture Committee for the efforts made by Mr. París to make Parliament heard and not to be ignored in such a clear and obvious way by the Council and the Commission as it has been so far.
Mr. President, first of all, I would like to join the congratulations of the rapporteur, Mr. Capulas Santos, for his excellent work.
I believe he has found balance and moderation in his report.
I think the important thing at this point in the debate is to send a message of stability to our farmers.
European farmers need stability and solutions more than ever.
Sufficient transitional periods are necessary, as well as maintaining specific measures that are necessary for sectors in difficulty.
Madam Commissioner, the same solutions do not apply to all sectors.
And we must remember that we have sectors that are going through real difficulties.
The common agricultural policy should not be the problem, but the solution, and for that we need a strong first pillar.
We believe and are committed to rural development, but we do not believe that the modulation proposed by the Commission is the solution.
It is not about strengthening rural development at the expense of the first pillar.
We agree that the single payment scheme needs to be simplified and market instruments need to be reviewed.
But that doesn't mean dismantling them.
If we do it right, we will be laying the foundations for a common agricultural policy beyond 2013. If not, we will be destroying the activity of many European farmers.
We are facing a long-awaited plan for the fruit and vegetable sector, not only because of the difficulties it is going through, but also because of the worrying decline in consumption.
We are faced with a plan to promote public health. I believe it should be a European plan and I also defend full community funding.

I do not agree that parents can enter the co-financing because it will be the same as always: parents who can contribute money, their children in schools will consume fruits and vegetables, and those who do not will be left out of the program.
I think it has to be a community-funded plan so that its distribution is homogeneous.
Therefore, I also want to emphasize that the emphasis must be on educational measures.

It is not just about a student eating an apple, but about knowing what kind of apple they are eating, knowing its nutritional properties, and understanding the beneficial effects that this fruit has on their health and development.
Of course, it must be products of all quality guarantees, giving priority, if possible, to seasonal fruits, and when possible, I defend the community origin of our fruits and vegetables.

I believe that the beneficial effects of this plan, which I applaud and for which I want to congratulate the commissioner, will be noticed immediately, of course, for the present and future health of our children and their education.

Food, but also, I believe, very important for the fruit and vegetable sector, a productive sector that constitutes a genuine European cultural heritage, because thanks to it we can enjoy a balanced, healthy and varied diet.
I think it is worth betting and investing in this plan for distributing fruits and vegetables in our schools.
I think the budget is a bit short, because I repeat that I defend the full community funding of a plan as ambitious as this.
Mr. President, I ask you not to include these first words, please, in the sick time machine.
My first words are to join the message of condolences expressed by this House towards Mrs. Klaas and, above all, to congratulate the rapporteurs.
Now I am starting.

I congratulate the rapporteurs because with these two proposals we are taking a qualitative step towards a common immigration policy and we are entering the promotion of legal immigration, a key pillar of the global approach we defend.
The general framework of rights and the single residence and work permit for legal immigrants must be extended to the largest number of workers.
That is why the socialists are asking that no category of workers be excluded.
The so-called blue card provides an opportunity for immigrants to settle with their families and work in our countries.
It opens a unique door to twenty-seven labor markets.
Now, not only highly qualified workers should enter through this door.
Therefore, we hope, Commissioner, that the Commission will soon present its proposals regarding the other categories of work.
Honorable members, we must fight against the brain drain.
This blue card should not become a passport that favors a bloodbath of vital human resources in developing countries.
Therefore, from the Socialist Group, we want that for every qualified professional who comes to Europe, we pay for the training of a new professional in the country of origin.
Finally, Europe must be an attractive destination not only for talents coming from outside the Union, but also for ours.
In 2007, almost three hundred highly qualified Europeans left to work outside the Union.
Let us do everything possible to keep them in the European House.
Madam Vice President, do you think that the closeness or distance of the candidates from the voters has to do with the degree of participation in the European elections?
European? Do you agree that a state of forty-five million inhabitants should have only one constituency for the European Parliament elections?
European, what can the Commission do so that the states with a larger population can have constituencies closer to the citizens?
Excuse me, but I didn't hear that the Vice President answered my questions.
Thank you very much, Madam President. You have given me a lot of information on the topic you were raising and I appreciate that detailed information.
I think the Commission's new stage is important, and above all, the Bamako project of a European Union immigration center.

I know it has just opened, which is probably very soon, but the question I ask the Commission is, in the event that the Bamako-Balí immigration project yields good results, does the Commission think it is possible to extend that experience to the rest of the countries on the southern shore of the Mediterranean?
I appreciate the response on behalf of Mr. Yáñez, but I must say, Commissioner, to Mr. Michel, that his actions, words and gestures are very necessary in direct contact.
We are really working with the Cuban democratic opposition to fulfill the Council's priority conclusions and reduce the effects of the terrible Castro dictatorship in favor of freedom.
Mr. President, on behalf of the Socialist Group, I would like to express my Group's strongest rejection of the murders being committed in this region of Somalia, invoking the name of God.
Few atrocities have been committed by someone who has not invoked the name of God or a religion.

Specifically, the way this atrocious murder was committed, we already know, a 13-year-old girl who is raped and then accused of adultery, and five men, if you can call them men, rush to stone her and even prevent someone from trying to save her in a stadium occupied by a thousand people.

This, combined with the acts of piracy that this year on the coasts of Somalia have reached the level of almost a hundred kidnapped ships, constitutes an absolutely unacceptable humanitarian situation.
The international community cannot remain impassive in the face of this.
It cannot remain impassive in the face of cowardice, in the face of religious invocation to commit atrocities.
Therefore, we must restore order by supporting the legitimate government of Somalia to regain control of the entire country and to establish a state of law that respects human rights.
I believe that we have rarely been presented with such a clear situation that imposes obligations on us.
I don't think we can remain impassive here, in this community of 500 million people and 27 countries, the most important in the world, without intervening in that situation.
I don't know how it can be done, but I certainly believe that it must be done and that we must intervene quickly.
The Socialist Group does not agree with the amendments that have been presented at the last minute, which were not negotiated at the time.

We support the text of the joint resolution and we hope that this will be the beginning of a greater concern of the European Union for this type of humanitarian issues and for the rejection of the abusive use of religious concepts to commit atrocities in the name of God.
I believe that the rapporteur and the speakers who have preceded me have highlighted the characteristics of this proposal for a directive from the Parliament and the Council.
It is about the recognition that weapons and ammunition are also within the internal market, although of course with a series of limitations.
These are not normal goods, they are not candies or entertainment objects, but objects that require precise control.
Of course, there are limitations in the Treaty itself, article thirty and article two hundred and ninety-six, which give the States important responsibilities in this matter.
And the fact that we have a common market does not prevent states from being obliged to comply with safety standards and, with the right, to apply them when their own safety is endangered.

The work done in the Committee on Legal Affairs and in the opinion committees that have collaborated with them, in agreement with the Council, under the expert leadership of the rapporteur, Mrs. Ruile, has been very positive.
I think the text we are presenting today is quite balanced.

Basically, despite the many amendments that seem to be on paper, today we are limited to one amendment, which is amendment 63, which is the one that captures the spirit of compromise, and in that amendment you can see a well-articulated, coherent text that will allow the functioning of this entire market.
Mr. Toubón has highlighted that this is related to other international texts.

For example, the adoption of the Oslo Convention this month, the signing of the Oslo Convention on the prohibition of cluster munitions, also the Convention on the limitations of anti-personnel mines, and a whole series of international agreements and even European Union standards aimed at limiting the use of weapons.

I believe that our model is not the model of free movement of arms at any time, but of a regulated market, controlled by the States and also controlled from now on by the European Union institutions themselves.
Madam President, Commissioner, this proposal came from the Commission more than a year ago, with very ambitious goals.
During this time, financial upheavals have occurred in the world that seemed to be going to sink these measures, but finally a balanced agreement has been reached.
It doesn't satisfy almost anyone one hundred percent, but it is a good agreement that maintains the final objectives, but makes the means to achieve them more affordable for companies.

That is why we have to thank and congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Doyle, the rapporteurs of the other political groups and the French Presidency, especially because their work has made it possible to achieve a good result for everyone.

I trust that in the near future, circumstances will allow us to be much more ambitious and that other countries will also join this crusade of the fight against climate change that we want to carry out in Europe.

Mr. President, Commissioner, this was a good proposal, as it came out of the Commission, not only because of the sulfur reductions, but also because of its new article seven bis, which required suppliers to.
The gradual reduction of greenhouse gas emissions and because it solved the old problem of vapor pressure for bialcohol gas mixtures in countries like mine, where there are warm summers.
This was precisely what didn't pass the vote filter in the Environment Committee, and this worried us a lot.

Today we have an agreement on the table that softens the application of article seven bis and that takes up the vapor pressure waiver, of course, tightening the conditions for accessing the exception.
And, as in the rest of this climate package, the agreement does not satisfy everyone one hundred percent, but it is still acceptable to everyone.

I would like to thank Mrs. Corbey for her excellent work, for the receptivity she has shown in solving problems, also to Mr. Turmes and, of course, to the French presidency, who have also made a great show of effectiveness here.
As the report says, according to estimates from 2007, Zimbabwe has a population of twelve million, of which almost half are starving.

Life expectancy is thirty-six years, and only forty percent of the country's teachers are working, and only a third of the students attend class, so Mugabe is not only killing the present, he is killing the future.
The repression and mutilation of human rights is also a daily occurrence.
Human rights defenders in Zimbabwe have systematically been the target of arbitrary detentions, arrests and torture.
The legislation introduced by the government severely restricts freedom of expression, assembly, movement and assembly.
I would like to mention several of them, since the government has introduced increasingly repressive rules, which have been used against these human rights activist defenders.

For example, the law on access to information and protection of privacy, used by the government to effectively silence journalists, the law on public order and security, which has severely limited the freedom of assembly and hundreds of.

Human rights defenders, including independent media workers, have been arbitrarily arrested, as well as the law on private voluntary organizations, re-established in 2002 by the government and allegedly used to intimidate and harass NGOs.
Madam President, in my mother tongue, Basque, which is not official in this House, Mugabe means without limit, a good nickname for this character.

The dictator of that African country is not just one more on the long list of dictators that, unfortunately, we have on this planet, but I dare say that he holds one of the top ten positions of dictators.
I believe that in the EU we have to do the impossible so that this character leaves and ends his days sitting in front of a human rights court.
We wish Zimbabwe a happy year 2009 without Mugabe.
We have a motion for a resolution on Nicaragua, which takes into account different aspects.
Firstly, there is an allegation of fraud, at least in two municipalities, Nicaragua and León, and this tarnishes the election result of November 9.
On the other hand, we have a government that has taken care of solving some of the problems that eliminate human rights in Latin America.
Specifically, poverty, illiteracy, infant mortality, the availability of drinking water and the lack of ownership of indigenous land.
So, when examining the case, we have to distinguish the two aspects perfectly.

On the one hand, we have to promote human rights and we have to defend human rights in the traditional sense as political rights, and on the other hand, we have to encourage the Nicaraguan government to continue its function of helping the sectors that need it most in the country.
Of course, we have to ensure that the opposition can exercise its function, we have to oppose fraud, but we also have to defend the actions of NGOs.
However, a balanced result must be achieved.
The Socialist Group has presented several proposals for oral amendments, trying to channel the final text so that it is more balanced with regard to the allegations of.

violations of fundamental rights, with regard to the criminal or non-criminal nature of the investigations, and with regard to the number of municipalities in which the effect has been some kind of derogation.

In short, we want to condemn the alleged infringement of fundamental political rights, but without going to the extreme of putting the Nicaraguan government in a difficult situation to continue fulfilling its function of supporting the most needy layers of society.
Mr. President, on the situation created in Nicaragua by the attacks against some human rights defenders, against some of the fundamental freedoms and against democracy.

It is not necessary to mention here now Zoila América, Ernesto Cardenal, Carlos Mejía Godoy, Jarquín, Sergio Ramírez, or so many other Nicaraguans who today feel betrayed in their hopes for a better Nicaragua.
In November 2006, Mr. Ortega democratically asked and obtained from the Nicaraguans what he called a new opportunity.
Today we already know what he wanted it for.
Since then, arbitrariness, nepotism and corruption have been installed in the government institutions, which culminated in the electoral fraud of the elections of November 9.

Previously, very serious decisions had been made, such as the cancellation of the legal personality of some opposition parties, threats and intimidation of members of civil society, journalists and the media.
President Ortega called the governments of the European Union flies that stumble over filth and called the external aid that Nicaragua received crumbs.
He soon understood that there was not enough Venezuelan oil to do without that development aid.

When we are about to enter a decisive phase of the negotiation of an association agreement between the European Union and Central America, the Nicaraguan government must know that it will always find an ally and a friend in us.

But for us, the demand for respect for human rights, freedom of expression and democracy in general is a condition that we do not give up because we believe that the people of Nicaragua benefit from it in particular.
On November 9th, municipal elections were held in Nicaragua.
As in previous occasions, this electoral process has been called into question from the point of view of democratic legitimacy, with accusations of fraud being made and.
demonstrations and clashes between supporters of different political parties, with the result of numerous injuries and a deepening of the political crisis that this country is suffering.
Two political parties have not been able to run in local elections, which is unacceptable because it curtails the fundamental right of all citizens to political participation.

On the other hand, we have received direct testimonies from representatives of human rights organizations who have informed us of the existence of a questioning of the judicial system by civil society.

on the existence of administrative repression mechanisms that have taken up to seventeen social movement organizations to court, on the persecution of independent journalists and even the European Commission delegation.

For all these reasons, we want to raise our voice and make an appeal, first to the political parties to condemn the acts of violence carried out by their followers, and second to the government itself to reopen spaces for participation.

citizen, that freedom of expression is respected, that marches are stopped and that all NGOs can receive aid from international cooperation, not only those from Venezuela, for pro-governmental associations.
Similarly, that the penalty for therapeutic abortion be repealed in cases of danger to the mother's life.

And, finally, we also want to ask the Commission that the negotiations of the Association Agreement between Central America and the European Union remind Nicaragua that it must respect the principles of the rule of law.

democracy and human rights, all without prejudice to the fact that we, from Europe, continue to provide our assistance for the development and well-being of the Nicaraguan people, who we hope will have the best possible future.
Madam President, I am going to refer to the Breyer report.
I must say that European farmers are fully aware that in the use of phytosanitary products, particular attention must be paid to human health and also to environmental protection.
However, the sector is deeply concerned because the European Parliament does not understand the impact that this Regulation may have in the future.
And there are assessments of its potential impact that indicate that, due to the low availability of phytosanitary products in the future, it will be very difficult to.
control of pests and diseases that affect the cultivation of a large amount of food, specifically all Mediterranean products, as well as the cultivation of ornamental plants and cut flowers.
I am fully aware that the agreement adopted in the trilateral dialogue was the result of a tough negotiation and I can only acknowledge the work done by the rapporteurs.

However, it should be taken into account that the temporary definition of endocrine disruptors will lead to the disappearance of a large number of active substances, especially insecticides, which are of key importance for agriculture.

Producers must have at their disposal a sufficient amount of active substances to effectively and safely combat any plant disease or pest, bearing in mind that the danger is often not in the product, but in the misuse of it.
For all these reasons, the Spanish delegation of the EPP/ED Group supports the proposals that request an impact assessment and will vote in favor of the amendments.
Mr. Stardy's, which I myself signed, regarding endocrine disruptors and those that promote the availability of phytosanitary products in case of an emergency.

Moreover, if this Regulation is adopted in accordance with the agreement reached, the effects will be a reduction in food production and an increase in prices, which will lead to the importation of the same foods that we do not produce treated with the products we are prohibiting.
Mr. President, Mr. Capato, your report is full of goodwill. The most obvious proof is that it did not deserve any amendment during its processing in the Committee on Civil Liberties.
It was you who introduced eighteen amendments to your own report.
And these amendments are the ones that have introduced a radicality to that report, let's say, in general terms, which raises very serious doubts for me.
I would like to present the amendments you have proposed in four different bodies, which you have proposed yourself, I insist, in a report that received the support of all groups at the beginning.
Some are impossible. You ask for some things that are impossible.

For example, Mr. Capato, you are asking for things for which there is no legal basis yet. For example, as long as the Treaty of Lisbon does not come into force, it will be impossible to harmonize the regulations of the different committees.
Something similar to what Commissioner Wallström just said. Or you ask, for example, that we declare the year 2009 the year of transparency. We are late, there is no deadline.
Therefore, you are asking for things that are impossible.
In addition, it asks for some others that are unadvisable.
For example, you are asking for transparency in the meetings of the political groups.
No, no.
that privacy is needed. Privacy is a political good.
If I want to disagree with my party, to maintain an opposition, I want to do it in private, and that is not a lack of transparency.
Transparency must be demanded in public bodies, but not within parties where debates must be guaranteed within privacy.
Therefore, I cannot continue with that.
There are some other assessments you make, Mr. Capato, that are uncertain.
For example, you say that ninety percent of legislative activity is through comitology.
That is a reckless exaggeration, Mr. Capato.
And, in addition, comitology implies transparency rules in itself.

If we are now going to create more mechanisms, more bureaucracy, more controls, we will be going against what we want to pursue, which is transparency, which is something that is very close to simplicity.
And, finally, before the President draws my attention, because I am already consuming my time, there are some things that are unnecessary.
For example, I understand that it is very attractive for public opinion to say transparency in the activity of the deputies, that it is known that they dance in the plenary sessions.
It is already known, Mr. Capato.
Or, if they go to the commissions, it is already known if there is a record of all of them, they are accessible to all citizens.
or the debts they charge. We already know, Mr. Capato.
That is to say, it is perfectly possible for a citizen to have access to that information.

Therefore, I understand that it is very nice for the public and that it is very nice to defend transparency, but I want you to know that transparency is making things look like they are, and when one contributes to things not looking like they are, Mr. Capato, then we are not contributing to transparency.
Thank you for your generosity, Mr. President.

horror at the repeated scene of children murdered and women torn apart in their infinite suffering after the bombings of the ghetto that Gaza has become.
The same horror that Picasso painted in his Guernica, our Guernica, devastated by the Junckers of the Condor Legion seven decades ago.
pain in solidarity with so many victims of so much suffering.
And shame for the inability of all of our states, the European Union and the international community, first to prevent and then to put an end to the criminal aggression we denounce.
Shame and indignation for so much lies, ambiguity and talk.
Shame, because we know exactly what is happening and we do not act with the necessary and enforceable force and coherence.
Therefore, history will hold many accountable as accomplices of the crime, at least for omission.
Because better late than never and because it is essential to keep a door to hope open, the European Union must support the late Security Council resolution.

We must ensure that it is strictly observed, and we must strictly observe our Association Agreement with Israel, which provides for its suspension in the face of behaviors such as those that are taking place.

We must clearly and decisively tell Israel to stop killing, to allow the wounded to be healed and to feed the damaged, and that its attitude towards international law must have consequences in its relations with Europe.
I would like to greet the few young European cooperatives who are suffering alongside the people of Gaza, particularly Alberto Arce.
They represent the best of the values of solidarity and freedom of this Europe of ours, which must be consistent in this terrible conflict.

Madam President, Commissioner, as we can see, in recent times the textile sector has been suffering from a major crisis that has led to numerous company closures, relocations and unemployment, facts that are concentrated precisely in regions specialized in this activity.

In the face of this current economic crisis situation, the European Commission should act quickly alongside the Member States to mitigate the socioeconomic effects of this restructuring, which is especially dramatic for the affected territories and families.

I think it is necessary to provide assistance to workers in the textile and garment sectors with social measures, with plans for companies that are under restructuring and are currently in serious trouble.
It would be desirable to allocate a substantial part of the Globalization Adjustment Fund to the restructuring and reclassification of the textile sector.
In particular, small and medium-sized enterprises, which make up the sector in the European Union and suffer the most from the effects of market liberalization.
On the other hand, it is necessary to re-establish the control system for imports from abroad, especially in terms of volume, from China.
It is not at all about promoting trade barriers.
It is about compensating for the negative effects of such an important transformation, and we must not forget that the European Union is the second world exporter of textile products and clothing.

That is to say, it is necessary to guarantee the best conditions for access to third-country markets, which are essential for the future of the textile and confection industry based in the European Union, and especially for SMEs.
All of this, of course, always guaranteeing fair competition based on the promotion of environmental and social standards in these countries.
In this sense, publishing correct information to the consumer, for example, with the regulation on the Made in indication, which, as far as we know, has not been implemented, would be very useful.
Among other things, it would involve subjecting imported products to the same safety and consumer protection requirements as those manufactured within the European Union.
Mr. Romeva, the Spanish government, do not worry, will cooperate as it has always done.

I would like to remind you that in this matter, the Spanish Minister of Foreign Affairs, Miguel Ángel Moratinos, was the first to appear before the Investigation Committee and to answer all the questions, including yours.

This is why we have been denouncing the inhuman and insulting torture and treatment committed at the Guantanamo military base in the name of the fight against international terrorism for some time now.
Therefore, we applaud Obama's decision to suspend trials for four months and his goal of closing the prison within a year.
Now, despite the responsibility falling on the US government, the Union cannot look the other way and must offer its collaboration to achieve the closure of the detention center.
We must also consider the possibility of hosting prisoners from countries where human rights are not guaranteed if the United States does not request it.

Then we will have to give a common European response, in which the Spanish government will participate, in respect of the international legal framework and in the case-by-case analysis of the legal situation of each citizen, of each detainee, the origin and detention and their situation.

Mr. President, there are various cases of languages of historical European peoples that, because they are not constituted in the state, are not allowed to be used in the debates of this Parliament, and this is a democratic and representative deficit.

One of these cases is the Basque language of the Basque Country, which is not a minority language but an official one, at least in the southern part of the Basque Country, which administratively falls under the Spanish state.

But the same thing does not happen, and do not take it personally, Commissioner, with the Basque Country, which is attached to the French state, whose president, before the UN Assembly, states that denying respect for national identities and languages is fueling humiliation and that without that respect there will be no peace in the world.
And then, neither the Basque, nor the Breton or Occitan Corsican have the slightest official consideration, nor do they have support to respect and promote their use.

Therefore, I ask that the Fundamental Rights Agency ensure and work to ensure that the rights of the mother tongue of no European people are violated within the Member States, nor that their inhabitants are discriminated against, and that all of them are considered official within their respective territories.
Skerry Casco, Jan Andreok, Suel Laguncha Gaitik, Europa Co. and Kuncha Agustín Alde.

Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank our rapporteur, Claudio Fava, for his great work in reaching a common position with the Council, which includes many improvements proposed by our House.
With this Directive, we demonstrate once again our commitment to building a common migration policy based on a global approach.
The approach of this Directive is clear: to fight against the mafias, punish unscrupulous employers and protect exploited immigrants who do not have any kind of social protection.
We want the unfair misery wages for immigrants to disappear, which also distort average wages, especially in sectors such as construction, the countryside, domestic service or hospitality.
These measures require great courage and political will, as there are many created interests and a lot of money that moves in the underground economy.
Precisely in difficult times it is more important than ever to manage migratory flows intelligently, with generosity, but with responsibility.
It would be easy to fall into the temptation not to try to tackle the underground economy.
We cannot look the other way and leave about eight million irregular immigrants in a situation of defenselessness, with working conditions close to slavery.

Honorable members, if we want this Directive to be effective, we need strict inspections and economic and even criminal sanctions in the most aggravated cases, which have a deterrent effect on employers.
We will thus be able to reduce the underground economy stock exchange and cut off the migratory incentive that generates the possibility of working irregularly.
It must be clear that the only option to work in Europe is the legal way.

Therefore, we want to continue with the global approach and we ask the Commission, Commissioner, Mr Baró, to present the new blue cards, in quotation marks, for the other categories of work as soon as possible.
Dear colleagues, Mrs. Ferrero-Waldner, Mr. Solana, I would like to start by thanking the three rapporteurs for their work and, as shadow rapporteur for the report on the CFSP, I will refer to
I would like to start by congratulating Mr. Saris Volski on the result of his work and on the collaboration that the other groups have offered to achieve a consensual result.

Just as this Parliament has repeatedly called for the European Union to provide itself with the necessary instruments to speak with one voice in the world, the House itself also knows how to show cohesion around the evaluation and promotion of the major priorities in the common foreign and security policy.

The efforts of our group, the Socialist Group, have gone in a double direction, on the one hand, to introduce or reinforce major issues that are key to us in a transversal manner to all foreign policy, such as the fight against climate change, the promotion of the.

peace on the entire planet or a commitment to human development. On the other hand, propose elements of rebalancing between the geographical priorities of the CFSP with respect to how they originally appeared in the text, if they did, or introduce them as a new element if they were absent.
In this way, we have advocated, for example, for a greater clarification of the relationships between the institutional and cooperation frameworks involved in the recently defined Eastern dimension.
We have defended greater diversification and greater relevance of relations with Africa, a continent that we often only remember when wars of special virulence occur, and often not even so.

Regarding Latin America, we wanted the current negotiation processes of association agreements to be reflected, the first of a bi-regional nature that the European Union will conclude in its entire history.

As for the Mediterranean, we have opposed a reductionist approach that only talks about security, to include, instead, all the rich political, economic and sociocultural heritage contained in the Barcelona process.

As for the amendments for the plenary session, our group has not presented any, believing that, in some way, the balance achieved with the commitments is reinforced, and therefore we will oppose most of the amendments in order not to weaken the commitment reached in the Foreign Affairs Committee.
Mr. President, the Venezuelan referendum has ended with a yes victory, elegantly recognized by the democratic opposition.

It is no less true that there was no equal opportunity in the campaign and that the officialism had the overwhelming support of the entire state apparatus, while the opposition has suffered constant harassment and coercion.
Even under these conditions, the country has been practically divided into two halves and it will be very difficult to build the future with just one of them.
The European Union must promote dialogue, inclusion and consensus among Venezuelan political and social actors for the good of the country.
It is not with visceral attitudes, discriminations or insults that we will help Venezuela find its democratic, pluralistic and free path.
In this sense, we criticize the decision of the Venezuelan government to expel a Spanish MEP and, even more so, the way in which such expulsion was carried out, but we call on this House to avoid

that our representatives make statements during their visits to third countries that violate the current local legislation, and even less that they insult a head of state, no matter how much he is criticizable.
With these attitudes, we are committing future missions of the European Parliament to other countries.
Mr. President, I have just arrived from Venezuela, where I was invited by your electoral power as a member of an international electoral accompaniment group for the referendum of the 15th.

The European members of that group have presented a report to the National Electoral Council with a positive overall assessment of the process in terms of its organization, transparency, participation, free and secret exercise of the right to vote and security in all its phases.

Regarding the statements of Deputy Herrero to a Venezuelan television station, he pointed out that they were intended to delegitimize the ongoing electoral process, they are making serious accusations against the democratic institutions of that country, and they are interfering in the internal politics of a sovereign country.
Our Parliament should not promote any kind of confrontation with the democratic institutions of Venezuela.
On the contrary, it would be up to the Member of Parliament to explain to this House about an action that affects all of us.
The Committee on Budgets believes that the clear limitation of each of the budgetary instruments is of the utmost importance.
Therefore, the most realistic option seems to be the creation of a new instrument for actions different from the public development aid of the countries that fall within the scope of this Regulation.
From a budgetary point of view, the proposed funding from the Development Committee does not seem appropriate, since this money does not exist.
Not having those lines with a credit amount assigned in a multi-year manner. There is a credit for 2009, but not for beyond.
In any case, since the financing of this new cooperation instrument must be compatible with the 2007-2013 financial framework, it is advisable to
Remember the importance of the mid-term review of the financial framework, which should allow for an adjustment of the maximum limits of the different headings.
Well, at this late hour on Monday, the Commission will probably have other things that worry it more than this report.
In short, what we are doing is nothing more than responding to a Commission report, a report on the application of Regulation 1206/2001 of the Council.
Council of May 28, 2001, on cooperation between the jurisdictional bodies of the Member States in the field of obtaining evidence in civil or commercial matters.

We are in an area that is not really community-based, it is an intergovernmental area in which, through the Council, through the Regulation, it has been attempted to stimulate cooperation between these judicial bodies.
But in doing so, I believe there is a certain lack of rigor on the part of the European Union.

That is to say, certain measures have been planned, for example, the issuance of practical guidelines, the use of electronic means, etc., but I recognize that it is quite difficult for the Commission to take action.

I don't know what the Commission has achieved or plans to achieve, but I think it is quite difficult to achieve due to the enormous difficulty that this form of intergovernmental cooperation constitutes.

That is to say, we are asking the judicial authorities to collaborate with each other, we are talking about 27 countries, judicial authorities that speak 22 different languages, with very different legal systems among themselves, and we are trying to achieve results.
The Commission has found that the results are not good, that there is a huge delay in these cooperation mechanisms and, of course, that we do not have the means to do so.
The ideal would be to have material means.
For example, what could the Commission do to provide judicial bodies, especially those of a lower level, with technological elements such as a video conferencing system?
Video conferencing may be a utopia in many small courts of the European Union as a whole, but it seems to be the only way to do it.
I believe that the European Union should rely on existing institutions, specifically the European Judicial Network.
We would have to strengthen this institution so that the judges themselves, through their cooperation systems, could develop this type of communication.
On the other hand, everything related to the training of judges is fundamental.
This is something that the Commission cannot do on its own either.
But the Commission can stimulate the development of this type of training courses in Community law and in the knowledge of the different legal systems.
Then there is a huge difficulty, which is the problem of languages, that is, how can a Spanish judge communicate with a Finnish judge with two such different languages.
It cannot be expected that judges, in addition to having to handle their own law, which is already quite complex, are obliged to have knowledge for this type of code.
What can we do from a practical point of view to facilitate the task of interpretation and translation for judges?
Translation, that is, what could we do to help them do it?
By presenting this report, do not express any kind of rigor or harshness towards the Commission.
I think the work is quite difficult.
What I would like to know, taking advantage of the fact that we have a commissioner here who is interested in this topic, is what the commission thinks can be done to be able to give more.
I am strict with this regulation from 2001, which is a bit imprecise, a bit voluntarist, and I do not know if it can have any practical consequences or if it can be made progress with it.
Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I am very pleased to be able to conclude this legislature with the final approval of the last of the maritime packages.

However, I remember that when I arrived at the European Parliament in 1999, we suffered a major maritime accident, that of the Erika ship, near the French coasts, which gave the first block of legislative proposals aimed at tackling and avoiding accidents.
We thought we had already conjured the danger, but shortly after the coasts of Galicia were ruined by the spill from another accident even bigger than the first, that of the ship.

Since then, in the Transport Committee, we have worked on successive legislative packages, trying to overcome the excessive resistance we encountered from shipowners, oil companies, classification societies, and also from certain Member States that rejected our proposals because they considered them too demanding.

In these ten years, we have approved different directives and regulations, some of which we have had to review again because, due to the cuts made by the Council, they were not effective in their first drafting.

We approved the rules for the introduction of double-hull ships, the European Fund for major oil disasters, and the shelter ports, and now we review and approve the responsibility of sea passenger carriers, the investigation of the

maritime accidents, the Community tracking and information system on maritime traffic, the control by the port state and, finally, the regulation and directive on ship inspection and recognition organizations.
And all of this is good and desirable that it can come into force and be applied by all member states in the shortest possible time.
Therefore, I am satisfied.
But the legislature is coming to an end, I am leaving the Parliament and I am going with the pity of not having managed to establish the mandatory introduction of control systems that already exist.
They are patented to know when and how much waste of sentinels and fuel tanks has been illegally dumped into the sea by a certain ship.
That is, a kind of black box or tachometers that can be inspected by maritime authorities every time a ship arrives at port.

I believe we owe the marine environment better care and stricter procedures to tackle the pollution we produce, which, if we don't do it, will affect our food chain and our lives, making us pay a high price.
I trust that they won't have to spend another ten years to control illegal sea discharges more effectively and efficiently.
Mr. President, the revision of the Eurovignette Directive is a matter of great importance that concerns us all, especially the peripheral countries, which feel we are victims of this proposal.
The European Commission has decided to address the internalization of external road transport costs by attributing three new costs: air pollution, noise pollution, and congestion.

Although the principles that inspire the proposal, who uses pays and who pollutes pays, are reasonable, the proposed solution is by no means discriminatory for a sector that has been suffering the disastrous effects of the economic crisis for months.
Demonizing road freight transport, although it was not the goal, has proven to be the end.

This proposal, ladies and gentlemen, is inopportune and far from achieving the expected objectives of sustainable transport, it would be the death sentence for a large number of small and medium-sized European companies that employ thousands of people.

People in the European Union contribute daily to the distribution of goods, ensuring that the products reach their final consumer, a consumer who will see how their products become more expensive due to the application of these fees.
Honorable members, we need a competitive, sustainable and environmentally friendly transportation system, without neglecting the road, because at present it is the only way to get anywhere.
The modal shift remains a dream, far from being a reality.
Trans-European networks, sea highways, and cross-border connections remain, in some cases, projects and not reality.
Honorable members, when the titanium of the global economy sinks, it is not possible to ask the orchestra to continue playing, and even less for joy.

Mr. President, on July 15, 2008, the European Commission adopted a communication addressed to the Council and Parliament recommending the establishment of a strategic partnership between the European Union and Mexico.
For its part, the European Council of Foreign Relations, on the thirteenth of October, recognized Mexico as a strategic partner, pending the opinion of the Parliament on the matter.
Let us remember that already at the seventh meeting of the European Union-Mexico Joint Parliamentary Committee, held at the end of October last year, we said that a
The strategic partnership between Mexico and the European Union is a necessary impulse to strengthen and develop the true potential of our bilateral relations.
We point out the good moment of the relations between both parties and the positive balance of the current global agreement.

We insist on the need for our respective executives to strengthen collaboration in political, economic and cooperation matters, especially in the face of new challenges of all kinds arising from the financial and economic crisis that is shaking our continents.

With the great country that is Mexico, we share values and objectives such as the development of democratic forms of government, commitment to gender equality, the consolidation of the rule of law, equitable and sustainable development, and respect for human rights.
We advocate for closer cooperation in the fight against organized crime, terrorism and drug trafficking, based on the principles of shared responsibility and strict adherence to international law.
Consequently, we will support the proposal for recommendations on the European Union-Mexico Strategic Partnership, which will be submitted to Parliament this morning.
I would like to congratulate all the rapporteurs on the report on microcredit, because they have done a great job.
The Commission's initiative has undoubtedly improved.
I understand that the recommendations established here will allow us to be the basis for developing a genuine framework in the European Union for the microcredit sector.
which has been a success in many developing countries, even in some European ones, both as a mechanism of economic activity and as an instrument to improve social inclusion and job creation.
But it had not been transferred to the sector or the community context, and I believe it is an opportunity to do so, especially starting from the economic and financial context in which we are.
In this sense, it is a priority to reinforce the initiatives that are being advanced here, but more steps need to be taken.
The available funds for this microcredit support structure must be increased.
We need to facilitate the availability of loans for people and businesses, and in this sense, I would like to highlight, Madam President, the example of
The European guarantee for micro-credit loans as an instrument that can facilitate this access and that has been included in the report.
And I end by thinking that, without a doubt, this will lay the foundations for us to create a harmonious framework in the European context that will boost the microcredit sector.

Madam President, taking advantage of the fact that we are talking about the budget, I understand that we must mentalize so that next year we can negotiate the continuation of aid for coal, an indigenous source of essential energy.
And I say this in advance because, in an improper way, some high official, confusing public opinion, allowed himself to express the opposite opinion, leaking it to an economic publication.
Nothing of that sort.
I will have to continue supporting my country's coal after 2012, and I want this to be noted in the session diary.
Ladies and gentlemen officials, please comply with the current plan and then, from 2012, with the instrument that we will start negotiating with the sector next year.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, this question, as Mr. Boclan explained, is very timely given the diplomatic conference on the ship recycling agreement that is going to be held in May.
Therefore, I would like to congratulate Mr. Brok, not only for the question, but also for the resolution he has prepared.

In the Popular Party, we are in favor of the fight against the bad practices and methods that have been used to scrap ships, and therefore we support Mr. Brockland's motion for a resolution. But there are some points that worry us.
The first is section three, which he also pointed out, which says that ships as a whole must be considered hazardous waste and, as a consequence, must be within the scope of the Basel Convention.

We have presented an amendment on this section because there are different interpretations within and outside the European Union and we understand that the Basel Convention must be taken into account and not contradicted with it, but it must be the future international agreement on ship sinking that defines the details of its application.
The motion for a resolution also calls for a funding mechanism based on mandatory contributions from the maritime transport sector in its point fourteen.

We think it is a bit hasty to talk about mandatory contributions at this time, when it has not yet been decided within the IMO what system will be adopted for this funding, and I also think that the European Commission does not have a clear answer on this matter.
Finally, in point 15, the Commission is urged to clearly establish that the State with jurisdiction over waste is the State responsible.
We also do not believe that it is the Commission's responsibility to decide this, which should also be decided in an international agreement.

The important thing is to ensure consistency on the future Convention on the Recycling of Ships and the Basel Convention on the Transportation of Hazardous Wastes and their Elimination, all taking into account not only the Basel Convention but all existing legislation.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, the first thing I would like to do is congratulate the rapporteur, with whom we have a great deal of agreement regarding this program, and congratulate all of us, because in times of economic crisis it is essential to maintain a program like this, with clear positive social effects.

Although we are in the process of consultation from the European Parliament, we must send a clear political signal that in these times of economic uncertainty from Brussels and Strasbourg we are not exclusively concerned.

We are not only concerned about the recovery of the financial system, but we are fully aware that social policies, especially those that support those who need it most, the poorest in the European Union, must grow.

This food distribution program must continue to be considered part of the common agricultural policy, and here we agree with the Commission, because European agriculture has a marked social character, because it is an instrument that works, because now it is needed more than ever and because it must continue to work.

From the Socialist Group, just like the rapporteur, we are against this program being co-financed between the European Union and the Member States, as this would mean discrimination between States according to their wealth, and it could be the case that the program cannot be implemented in the countries that need it most.

It is not understood that now, when it is most needed, the Commission wants to save money from the community in the most social aspect of the CAP, especially considering that there are budget surpluses in the agricultural budget every year.
Full community funding is fundamental for us.
We need to ensure that this program reaches all countries and, above all, the most needy.
Forty-three million potential beneficiaries of this program are demanding a greater effort and in no case that budgetary expenditure is saved.
Austerity, yes, but not with the poorest.
And it is precisely to ensure that it reaches the citizen of all member states that the program must cover the entire route of the food distributed.

Therefore, from the Socialist Group, for which I am responsible for the report, we have presented an amendment so that all expenses derived from distribution, including those of transportation, storage, and administrative costs, are covered by Community funds.
We also agree with the rapporteur that food should be preferentially community-based and of high quality.
It is the position that is consistent with that maintained by this Parliament in other similar programs that we recently discussed in this House, such as the plan for distributing fruits in schools.
Nothing more and thank you very much.
We hope that the Commission will take into account the position of this Parliament when it is voted on and, above all, that the plan will be implemented in the European Union as soon as possible.
The Arctic region is one of the most fragile regions on our planet.
The consequences of unrestricted exploitation of their natural resources would be catastrophic not only for the immediate environment and the indigenous population, but for the world as a whole.

The thawing of large areas has brought these risks to the forefront, which makes it necessary to have a new global regulation to protect the Arctic, similar to the one that already exists for Antarctica, even taking into account the differences that have already been highlighted in the debate.

An international treaty is needed between all the parties involved, among which the European Union is undoubtedly, to protect its unique environment, ensure the fully sustainable nature of all types of human activities, and regulate navigation multilaterally through the new maritime routes that are becoming accessible.
The Arctic Council has been a model of cooperation for managing common problems during its several years of existence.

At this time of difficulty and uncertainty, we must take that spirit and that harmony to a higher level to prevent the states of the area or other international actors from engaging in geostrategic struggles, forgetting what should be the common goal, the preservation of a great shared heritage.
Mr. President, unlike the two speakers who have just preceded me, I agree with most of the speakers.
This is a good directive, an excellent directive aimed at protecting interpreters.
When it is said that we need to look for a smarter business model, what we are actually talking about is the end of intellectual property.
Because you can only do business if there is an established right.
We already have a right established at the national level.
The Commission, under the direction of Mr. Macrivi, has adopted a courageous initiative, a positive initiative, and I believe that the House must approve the commitment we have made.
This has been achieved in the area of the Committee on Legal Affairs thanks to the work of the rapporteur, Mr Crowley, and the various shadow rapporteurs, such as Mrs McGill and Mr Tugong.
I think it is a magnificent directive, a directive that will promote the creation of intellectual property.
And, in addition, this directive includes a few recommendations regarding the continuation of the work.

I believe that the approval of this report by this House, and I hope that the Council will align itself with the lines of the Council, the Commission and the Parliament, will serve to ensure that in the next legislature the

The Commission should continue on this path, make proposals to the Parliament and make progress in the area of intellectual property protection, which is essential for the development of our European Union as a great institution based on a common culture.
Mr. President, the information you give me is correct, but the impression that European parliamentarians and, ultimately, European citizens have is that we have a very dangerous gap in Community law.
At the moment, as tax requirements are being strengthened in each of the member states, mobility is almost impossible.
And when we ask the Commission, the reason for the pragmatic approach is that the Commission never finds support in the Council.

We are in a kind of vicious circle, by virtue of which the Commission refers us to the Council and the Council refers us to the Commission. But, in the meantime, the reality is that the citizens who live in this Europe that we want to build do not have the possibility of living in different countries or establishing relationships as a result of the heavy tax burden that the lack of tax harmonization can entail.
Can the Council do something to get us out of this vicious circle?
Madam President, for once I am glad that the headline is not there, that Mr. Tajani came, because Mr. Tajani has the advantage of being a European parliamentarian.
And as a European parliamentarian, I know that you have experienced the frustration that European parliamentarians have with regard to the application of Community law.

Now, in Parliament we tend to get involved with the Commission. I believe we are asking the Commission for an impossible mission, because all Community law and all the application of Community law is based on indirect application.

That is to say, the Commission has only a few officials at the headquarters where it receives some complaints and has some possibilities of action. But at this moment, in addition, the tendency is to limit budgetary powers, so the Commission will not have the possibility to do so.
All Community law, all the application of Community law is based on the actions of national authorities, national parliaments, national judges, national officials.
And here, in this regard, I don't think we can demand too much from the Commission.
What we have to do is help the Commission, and I believe that in Mrs. Frassoni's report there are some points that can be useful to achieve this application.
I am referring to those related to the correlation of directives, the collaboration of national parliaments and the actions of national courts.
Mr. President, two years ago, during a mission led by my colleague from the group present here, Marian, I had the opportunity to visit.
Sierra Leone and being present in this Court and being aware of the immense work that this Court was doing, not only for Sierra Leone, but for all of humanity.
The Special Court of Sierra Leone, as has already been said here, has certainly set a precedent.

A precedent because, as the Resolution indicates, it is the first international court funded by voluntary contributions, it is the first court to be established in the country where alleged crimes took place, and it is also the first court, as has already been pointed out, in which a former prime minister has been tried.

For all these reasons, not only because it is a precedent, but because it is a reference for other courts that have been created at its dawn, such as Rwanda, the former Yugoslavia, Cambodia or Lebanon, we consider it essential that this resolution be approved, on which we have been working together with the Court for several months.
Two years ago we passed a resolution to support its funding. Two years ago the court was going through a difficult period in which it was running out of.
I had no money and I didn't have enough support. We should also thank the European Commission for coming out to support this court financially.

Now we are asking for two things first: that the convicted people serve their sentences. The functioning of the court, which will end next year, is no longer at stake, but the legacy that this court will leave us. Secondly, obviously, all of this must be accompanied by greater funding.
In short, the Special Court of Sierra Leone is an example and a reference for all of us and for all the courts that have judged war crimes.

It is an example and a reference, and it is a lesson that the second poorest country on this planet is giving us, in which, when we entered the court, we saw a written slogan that was: Without justice, there is no peace.
And precisely for this reason we have a moral obligation, not only as Europeans, but as human beings, that the legacy of this Court remains permanent in history.

Mr. President, very briefly, as the honourable members will thank me at this time. Mr. Vice-President of the Commission, thank you once again, because you have demonstrated, as you did in the third package.

Maritime, whose impetus, its political category has been able to push for an agreement near the Council and make it possible for Parliament, the Council and the Commission to agree in this instance and in these last days when the legislature ends.
I think we should congratulate ourselves.
I certainly appreciate the close collaboration that the opinion rapporteurs have had, both in the Committee on Legal Affairs and in the Committee on the Environment.

I would like to thank and reiterate the work and collaboration of the shadow rapporteurs and, ultimately, I believe that the fact that tomorrow we adopt an agreement at first reading on such an important rule, which undoubtedly complements the work of the

The third maritime package is a success for this Parliament and for the European Union in the three institutions and justifies, once again, the co-decision procedure, which is useful and allows for constructive dialogue in favor of all citizens of the European Union.
I ran out of a minute. I want to answer the Commissioner, who knows about my friendship and my affection for her, and indeed about my friendship and my affection for Mr. Orban.
But the Commissioner has not said a single word about the Ombudsman's recommendation.
That is to say, the Ombudsman, who knows all the arguments that the Commissioner has given us, has made a precise recommendation that the Commission seems to ignore in all its extremes.

I don't even want Mrs. Cuneva to answer me because, obviously, she is not the one who has the data, but all the data she has given me is in line with what we knew and what the ombudsman also knows, and she doesn't tell us if it is indeed true.

Despite all this, and as the Ombudsman, who knows this, recommends that the rule be changed, he does not tell us if the Commission is going to assume what the Ombudsman asks and what the Parliament recommends based on what the Ombudsman has asked for.
Mr. President, I believe that the proposals for a regulation submitted to us by the Commission are important and necessary, and, on the other hand, it was also important and necessary that, from the

The European Parliament should insist on the principles that the two rapporteurs of the European Parliament, Mr. Svieska and Mr. Depré, have insisted on, and that is the principle of Community competition.
This is a matter of Community competence in which, for practical reasons, it is advisable to maintain certain competences of the States, but, as Mr. Barró said, limited in terms of scope and time.
Community competence is unavailable and neither the Council, nor the Commission, nor the Parliament have the authority to renounce those community competences.

Having established this, this is an exceptional procedure. I believe that the amendments we have discussed and presented, and which I believe will be approved by Parliament tomorrow, will allow the approval of this package of measures at first reading.

But I also hope that, on the part of the Commission, in the future, and based on this, we can make progress in the development of a genuine European private law, which is increasingly necessary, as Mr. Sogor has highlighted, for example, in his last speech.

We are talking about the problems that affect people the most directly, and to the extent that we are able to solve those problems of the people, people will realize that the European Union has a function.
In short, Mr. President, I would like to congratulate my colleagues, Mr. Debrey and Mr. Svieska, and thank the Commission and the Council for their willingness to collaborate with us on this issue.

Madam President, Commissioner, I have signed this Resolution and asked to speak on this issue because I witnessed the so-called expulsion, but in fact it was a kidnapping of our colleague Luis Herrero.

And, in addition, I was able to confirm that political persecution, the abuse of power by the Chavista regime, the intimidation of the opponent, the threat, the disregard for the dignity of people, and the torturous use of justice, among other things, are common in Venezuela.

The case of Manuel Chávez is the drop that has drunk the glass and given rise to this Resolution, but there are thousands of cases as bloody as his that are cited in the Resolution and others that are not.
As is the case of Ligio Cedeño, who was born in the humble Caracas neighborhood of Petare, well known for its danger and also because he voted for a mayor who was not part of the Chavista regime.
Eligio studied, thanks to the help of others, and specifically Citibank, he managed to found his own business, the Banco de Caracas, and then he lived normally helping those most in need.
Today, however, he is illegally imprisoned in a Caracas prison, after two years of being arrested without any coherent charges.
Their only crime is to be part of the economic oligarchy.
Another case is Nilson Moreno, student leader of the University of the Andes, who has been elected several times to the University Council and president of the Federation of University Centers.
He won the elections in 2003 for the current Minister of the Interior and Justice, and this is his crime.
Today he is accused of homicide, in a state of frustration, violent lascivious acts, and all this despite having been acquitted of such accusations.

Situations like yours are everyday life in this country, where the persecution of the opponent with the intention of excluding him from political life and discouraging dissent has become a daily reality.

However, from here it is necessary to send a message of hope to Venezuelan democracy, despite the difficulties, I am sure that democracy will prevail and that President Chavez will be deposed at the polls.
Madam President, Commissioner, it is indeed undeniable that progress has been made in recent times, but despite all the progress, the south of the Union is burning and burning more and more.
That is why the resolution that this Parliament has approved cannot be just another resolution that serves to highlight the great concern that other people's misfortunes cause us.
Forest fires are caused by one or another reason, but no one can deny that they feed on climate change.

And regardless of the responsibilities that may exist in some states or in some autonomous communities, the truth is that this Parliament must clearly call on the Commission to act quickly and to put all the resources at its disposal, which are not few, at its disposal.
Neither the victims, nor the damage suffered, nor the need for reforestation understand bureaucracy, nor can they understand budgetary shortcomings.
We must prioritize and act, and acting in this case means modifying strategies, mobilizing resources, increasing them and optimally coordinating preventive policies, demanding that the time come.

In this case, responsibilities are placed on the States that lack them, but assuming that this is not a problem of some States in Southern Europe and that climate change does not affect only some States, it affects everyone and is a common cause.
Therefore, one of the main tasks that this Parliament has closest to it must be to ensure that the European Union achieves clear commitments at the next Copenhagen summit.
Strong measures to minimize greenhouse gas emissions as much as possible, because they are obviously at the root of the fires, their causes, and these, in turn, are the causes of more climate change.
Therefore, approving this Resolution is now the challenge of this Parliament, for sure.
But that the Commission's challenge is met if, Commissioner, you really want to prevent the south of the Union, which does exist, from continuing to burn.
Mr. President, thank you very much for giving me the floor. I am addressing Mr. Barroso.

Mr. Barroso, I must tell you that I have been following you with great interest and great respect for a long time, since you were the governor of a country that is very close to us and very dear to us, which is Portugal.
I must tell you, however, that you have absolutely surprised me now.

I am surprised for two reasons, firstly, because you have shown contempt for the group in which I am present, the group of non-attached, not giving us even a minute of your time to come and tell us your political proposals.
We represent many European citizens and you have shown contempt for all our voters.
Secondly, due to the fragility of its political project, due to the poverty of its political proposals in the document Political guidelines for the next Commission.
Proposals that don't even include what you have defended throughout your own term as President of the Commission.
I was surprised in this regard that issues such as energy, which have been well addressed throughout your term, are now being addressed when you offer us your concerns for the next

Madam Commissioner, you ended your words by telling us that there is a crisis in the dairy sector, but you began by telling us that you had already taken all the measures and that the matter was being resolved.
Look, it is wise to rectify.
