And that is a Spanish saying that could be applied very well to the case that concerns us today.

The dairy sector has been suffering one of the most serious crises in its history for months, and despite this, because you do not want to give up, or the European Commission, or some of the governments, including mine, the Spanish government, which seem to be refusing to reverse the decisions of the CAP health check.
These decisions were made without taking into account the fragility of this sector and in a market context very different from the one that arose after that commitment was closed.
It seems that the member states either did not want to or could not see the storm that was coming at that moment.
The reform was outdated in a short time due to the great turnaround that the market has made, a turnaround that shows that the sector is completely at the mercy of price volatility.

The fact that large producers, such as France and Germany, countries that achieved the largest increase in their national production quotas in absolute terms in that agreement, are now asking for a review of the check decisions gives a lot to think about.

In my opinion, the member states were wrong and should have listened more carefully to the voices among which I am, who asked to postpone any kind of definitive decision on the future of the sector to 2011.
It's a shame that they didn't listen to us.
Listen, do it now.
Mr. President, this Parliament is the palace of chimera, it is the palace of dreams.
The Irish people, with their vote, with their strong vote, give us encouragement and strength to continue prospering and build a strong Europe and, above all, a federal Europe.
Only in this way, only in this way, would we deserve the title of legitimate heirs of the fathers of Europe, for whose work we are all here.

Mr. President, after overcoming the concern generated by the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon, it is time, in my opinion, to think about the treatment that will have to be given to the nationalist attitudes that so much hinder European construction in the future.
My idea is that these obstacles cannot be free.
With a cold head, it is time to think about the possible measures to be taken in the coming days and years.
This modest member of parliament wants a future Council president who is a man, or rather a woman, convinced of European federalism, who manages the.
The euro, which is in the Schengen area and which is identified and committed to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. Thank you very much, Mr. President.
That is, on behalf of the Commission, I would just have to add amen, but well, I had already prepared the intervention on behalf of the Socialist Group.

The breakdown of the constitutional order in Honduras has broken two decades of unpunished rule in Latin America and creates a perverse precedent for other countries, especially the weakest ones, as is the case now in Paraguay.
The European Parliament cannot and must not remain deaf and mute in the face of such a violation of the rule of law.

Both the Council and the Commission have unequivocally condemned the coup, supporting the mediation of President Arias, in line with the position adopted unanimously by the OAS with the support of the United Nations.

The self-proclaimed de facto president Michelete has failed to comply with the recently reached agreements, mocking the international community and preventing the return, among other measures, of the deposed president, Mr. Zelaya.

Under the current circumstances, the election of a new president in the elections scheduled for November 29th has an illegitimacy of origin, and its results cannot and should not be recognized by the international community.

The European Parliament would make a serious mistake if it sent a delegation to observe the elections, because this would be interpreted as a support for the coup d'état. The OAS has already ruled out sending an observation mission to these elections.
This Parliament has been criticized for being a guarantor of freedom, democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights.
As Baclar Havel said this morning, there can be no two weights or two measures.
We are all democrats here and, consequently, freedom activists. And, therefore, whether we talk about Cuba, China, North Korea or Honduras, our discourse must be firm against the liberticides.
Let us not be blinded by our ideological preferences.
There are no coup plotters or dictators of right or left, only liberticidal and repressive.
Many of us fear that things in Honduras will not change, and that this will have created a very dangerous precedent, and the doctrine of a temporary and not too cruel coup will have triumphed.

Mr. President, I would like to congratulate the members of the ENVI Committee and its President, Mr. Leinen, for the work they have done so that we can have a Resolution like the one we have and that we must approve with determination.
We cannot be satisfied with saying that we have enough with sectoral agreements, because talking about a retaliatory agreement is already admitting a part of the failure.
We have decided to approve this resolution, which has three noble aspirations.
One more obvious one is to avoid climate change with concrete proposals for reducing emissions and with a commitment to funding, and aspiring to a binding agreement, I say not of rattles.

And two latent aspirations: one is to start working sooner rather than later to have a common energy policy, as we once provided ourselves with a common agricultural policy because it was needed, and of course, that also includes regaining the trust of citizens in politics and politicians, which we are running out of in Europe.
In this sense, the success of the Summit will be the success of the three aspirations.
That is why I encourage the President, in office of the Council, to continue with his optimism, to push and negotiate everything he can to drag others to this success.

I don't know if the rulers of this multipolar world want to be called into question by history for not being able to reach a binding agreement, but I, as a deputy, and I believe all representatives of the people, cannot be called into question by history for not being able to achieve the binding commitment we have with humanity in Copenhagen to avoid climate change.

Today, there is no doubt about the European Union's commitment to the fight against terrorism, and thanks to the Stockholm Programme, we will continue to make progress in this area of freedom, justice and security, which is so necessary.

But, in my opinion, this fight has been based on mutual trust between the member states, but it is high time, and with the possibilities offered to us by the Treaty of Lisbon, to harmonize national legislations in the direction of not prescribing terrorist crimes, which should be considered crimes against humanity.

On the day this happens, no one in this Parliament or anywhere else will defend terrorists, as has happened, it happens and it can continue to happen, with the consequent damage to the victims of terrorism, who see how those who killed their loved ones are treated as heroes, while they suffer in silence.
I therefore ask this Parliament to promote or adopt the European Charter of the Rights of Victims of Terrorism, based on the defense of memory.

Mr. President, I would like to start by congratulating Mrs. McGuinness on this initiative, which highlights the important role that the CAP plays in meeting the needs of food supply on an international scale.

Now that the European Commission seems to want to reduce the weight of the CAP within the Community budget, it must be said very loudly and very clearly that the CAP is no longer a priority, but food sufficiency should be, and in the past decades it has been seen that without the CAP food sufficiency is very difficult, not to say impossible, to achieve.
Agriculture cannot be compared, therefore, to other sectors of the economy capable of prospering in a free market, because the food market is not a free market.

The farmer needs the support of the European Union in order to be able to carry out his business, and the Union needs the farmer in turn to maintain an agricultural model capable of providing sufficient and quality food to an increasingly demanding citizen.
I therefore believe that there should be a change of direction in the CAP, but not a disappearance.

To achieve this, it would be necessary to guarantee direct aid to farmers, as well as to re-establish a policy of managing agricultural markets that provides greater price stability, which would benefit not only farmers but also consumers and third countries.

It would be necessary to establish a framework of good practices to promote balanced relationships between the different agents of the food chain, avoiding abusive practices and promoting a fairer distribution of commercial margins.
In addition, a European consumer information policy is needed that emphasizes the efforts made by Community producers to comply with European Union environmental regulations.
environment, food safety and animal welfare, because Community producers have to compete with productions from third countries where very lower standards are applied to imports.

And these producers from third countries prefer to export to the European Union rather than supply the markets of their own countries for a sincere matter of profitability, with the endorsement of WTO negotiations.
According to a United Nations report, in 2009, around two hundred and seventy zero people were victims of human trafficking in the European Union.

With these figures in hand, it is necessary that the action of the European Union is primarily based on the protection of the victims, with special attention to the situation of women and children, who are the most vulnerable.
We cannot continue to watch this theater, this spectacle of sexual exploitation, which is unfolding before our eyes, indifferently.
That is why I fully support the request of this Parliament that assistance to the victims be unconditional, more decisive and more severe punishments, as Mr. Barrot has just told us.
That said, I would like to request the President and the Council to use all the European legislation in their hands, both existing and future, to protect the victims of human trafficking.

I believe that the proposal for a European order for the protection of victims, which I personally requested from the Spanish Presidency during the debates of the Stockholm Programme and which has finally come to light, will be an effective instrument to fight against these crimes.

I hope for a firm commitment, as we have already seen from the Spanish Presidency, so that this order offers the victims special protection measures that are effective throughout the territory of the European Union.

I hope that those of us who have the responsibility to act in the face of the most serious problems of our society will give a real and concrete answer to this very serious problem of human trafficking and that we will not just stay with good words.
We truly owe it to all the victims.
Mr. Zapatero, for a Spaniard like Picasso, it is an honor to welcome you here in the role of the President of the European Union.
There are many expectations and challenges that this period has, and we certainly cannot disappoint the expectations created.
that the citizens see that our renewed institutions are an instrument capable of providing solutions to real problems.
But we have put it because, Your Honor, you know that it is shared by us.
For the Spanish People's Party, this is a matter of the State and we will be behind your lordship in everything that we see as common interests of Europe and that is important for Spain.
It is an ambitious program and it is a program that I hope will be filled with content.
I would like people to see in that album of the Spanish Presidency, since it will surely be colorful and varied, that they see in each event a milestone on real problems that affect them.
The crisis is hitting the economies and unemployment seems like the fifth horse of the apocalypse.
You have had the honesty to admit that twenty percent of unemployment exists in Spain, but that does not make you incapacitated.
What I believe is that it forces us to produce a solution to a problem that we really have to solve together.
That was a real problem.
Time doesn't allow me to say many things, Mr. President.

But I do want to tell you that Spain has many challenges ahead of it, that I believe I have the security of Spain's capabilities as a nation and that I want to believe and I am sure that you will be up to our country.

We cannot disappoint these expectations in this time of Europe. On the other hand, the globalized world, and you have referred to it intelligently, produces new centers of power, and it is necessary for the European Union to play a more active and coherent role in defending its values and interests.
Otherwise, we risk being irrelevant.
Finally, Mr. President, the Spanish do not accept that anyone has the ability to make proposals to us.
We have that legitimacy.
What we also have to have is the humility to accept those advice of Don Quixote that Sancho gave him when he recommended humility in the dream of the government of the Barataria island.
I am glad to say that José Luis Zapatero has not failed to surprise European women with measures of great innovation and progress.
Of course, the formation of a truly equal government and the brave way in which it has brought gender equality and respect for the other to the national and European agenda.
Mr. President, I warmly congratulate you on your ambitious action program, of course, against gender violence, which is a social scourge.
The creation of a European Observatory on Gender Violence is a cutting-edge proposal that European women support and applaud.
Mr. President, on behalf of the Portuguese socialists, I wish you good luck.
You can count on our solidarity.
solidarity, women with shoes.
Mr. President, in a matter as serious as terrorism, we should not wait for events to act.
We should anticipate this, but we don't.
And, unfortunately, we are moving forward with an attack like the failed Detroit attack, which forces us today to make decisions that guarantee the safety of air transport.
Deciding on body scanners at airports is a responsibility that we cannot evade, ladies and gentlemen.
We can't keep waiting because terrorists don't wait.
Therefore, the Commission must ensure as soon as possible that the dignity and privacy of people will be preserved and that there will be no negative effects on health.
Once this is guaranteed, we have to make decisions for the entire European Union.

And to those who fear that fundamental rights will be violated, I will tell them that there is no higher right than the right to live. And those who love freedom above all, we need to live safely to feel truly free.
Mr. President, I believe that this crisis is an opportunity to move forward firmly and convincingly in the creation of a strong Europe.

In this strong Europe, it is likely that the expression improving coordination should be dispensed with, as it makes everything dependent on the subjects to be coordinated and rigorously refers to paralysis and indefinition.
We know that the finances and public debts of European countries will suffer as long as we do not move towards European financial integration and there are no Eurobonds issued.

In any case, European institutions can already take concrete actions. I do not insist on the words of coordination. On the one hand, there is the European Central Bank to harmonize financial supervision.
Good evening. I wanted to say that I did not come to this Parliament to applaud the newly issued law on abortion in Spain.

What worries me is human life, and I am worried above all, and I am here to defend the women whose lives are in danger because of gender violence, and to offer them a space in which they can live freely and safely.

The Resolution of this Parliament of February 2, 2006 recommends that the Member States adopt a zero-tolerance attitude towards all forms of violence against women and that they adopt the necessary measures to ensure better protection for the victims.
The Stockholm Programme, approved in this House, established a space of freedom, justice and security for all European citizens, and it considered the fight against gender violence to be a priority.

It reflected my request to the Spanish Presidency to promote a European order for the protection of victims of gender-based violence during its mandate, to ensure that victims of these crimes have the same level of protection in all Member States.

In a Europe without borders, the fight against gender violence should not have borders either, and the member states should strive to harmonize their legislation so that the idea that the fight against the mistreatment of women goes beyond the borders of the European Union is not just about the fight against violence against women.

Legislative obstacles and in the end we could offer at least within the European Union and we could protect the lives of women and their children. I therefore ask the Commission and the Council to do everything possible.

It is necessary and everything in its power to push forward this European order for the protection of victims, which is a very effective instrument to fight against the impunity of those who do not respect the dignity of women or their right to live freely and safely.

It has been a long time since Fidel Castro and his oligarchy ended the ideals of the Cuban Revolution, which were so much echo and illusion for the peoples of the whole world, for the most grenaded of the international youth.
However, what characterizes the Castro brothers'dictatorship at this moment is the wickedness towards political and conscientious prisoners, the wickedness towards their own people.
It reminds me of Franco Moribundo, with the mistreatment of political prisoners, which he also considered common, and his obsessive contempt for exiles.
Castro ends up as Franco, and all the enemies of freedom when they get entrenched in power.
But we must save lives and be in solidarity with those who fight and suffer.
It is our obligation as Europeans committed to democracy, freedom, and human rights.
Madam President, President of the Council, Commissioner, let us never again allow our silence to become complicity with the liberticidals.
We will never again allow a person who fought for their rights and those of all to die in Cuban or any other prison without our strong and firm voice being raised demanding their salvation.

Mr. Orlando Zapata Tamayo, a forty-two-year-old citizen, a colored bricklayer, who only asked for an improvement in prison conditions, died after eighty-six days of hunger strike and seven years in prison for demanding respect for human rights.
And in those seven years he was mistreated, humiliated, and insulted by his jailers, in the midst of, we must remember, a thick silence from the international community.
Other prisoners and human rights activists in Cuba are now on hunger strike, such as the psychologist and journalist Guillermo Fariñas.

Honorable members, the Resolution we are presenting today, which we are debating today and which we will vote on tomorrow, and which I represent on behalf of the Social Democratic Group, demands the release of all prisoners of conscience in Cuba.
It once again speaks in favor of a democratic transition and strict respect for fundamental human rights.
Let's not get into a topic that divides us for the moment, whether or not the common position should be maintained.
Let's focus on the issue of saving lives and human rights now.
And let us open a period of serene reflection in which we seek meeting places on the issues of future politics with Cuba.
But this text also has an important added value.
The fact that six political groups are presenting it expresses a new time of broad consensus in this House on the issue of human rights.

It should never again be stated that the European democratic right obeys the orders of Yankee imperialism, but it should also never again be said that social democrats are complacent or accomplices to the communist dictatorship.
Simply because both statements are false and the victims of the liberticides, wherever they are, must know that they will find us united in the unconditional defense of their cause.
Mr. President, I would like to thank Mr. Salafranca, who negotiated this text on behalf of the European People's Party, Mrs. Weber, from the Alliance of Democrats and Liberals Group, and Mr.

Mrs. Romeva, on behalf of the Group of the Greens, Mr. Kasutnik, of the Conservatives and Reformists, and other colleagues who have participated in this difficult, complicated but, I hope, successful effort tomorrow.

Finally, I would also like to thank the Spanish Prime Minister and the current President of the European Union, Mr. José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, for his encouragement and support in pushing forward this Resolution that we are debating today.
History will absolve me, it was the famous argument of a young lawyer who made his people vibrate.
History effectively absolves him of his rebellion against tyranny and then against the American blockade.
But with the same emphatic prosecution, this Parliament, which represents the largest space of freedom and democracy in the world, condemns the dictatorship that.
The people of Cuba suffer from the violation of human rights on the island, the impiety with political prisoners, and the contempt for their exiled nationals.
The judgment of history is clear.
With this Resolution, Members of all ideologies, we stand by the Cubans who are fighting.
We must avoid by all possible means the brutal repression they suffer, even by overcoming the so-called paralyzing common position.
I pay tribute to the poet Raúl Rivero in the last verse of his Habana: Do not impose taxes on affection, emptiness, suffocation, and bitterness.
The ruins of the homeland are safe.
Don't worry, colleagues.
We're leaving now.
This week was International Women's Day celebrated.
In this Parliament we had many posters in all the languages of the European Union saying that yes, violence against women can be stopped.

Today we are talking about violence in Mexico and it seems normal to me to recognize that Mexican women, both indigenous and non-indigenous, are the least protected victims by local and federal authorities.
Mexican women are victims of all forms of violence, from family violence to sexual violence and torture perpetrated by members of the army or police, and even murder.
Unfortunately, the Mexican authorities'responses have been ineffective so far, and that is why there is a correct talk of almost absolute impunity.
Our Resolution calls on the Mexican government to combat feminicides, a harsh but correct word when we see that almost all murders committed against women remain unpunished.
For example, in the State of Mexico, in the last four years only eleven percent of the criminals who murdered almost seven hundred women were convicted.
At the same time, it seems that women are the preferred victims of the judicial system.
There is no other way to explain how it was possible that two indigenous women, Alberta Alcántara and Teresa González, were sentenced to 21 years in prison and up to
They have now spent more than three years in prison for kidnapping six men from the Federal Research Agency alone during an incident in a market.
I hope that the judge who will decide on the appeal in this case in a week will realize the ridiculousness and injustice of the situation. But violence against women starts in the family.
I hope that Mexican lawmakers will soon improve the General Law on Women's Access to a Life Free of Violence, so that the types of violence and mechanisms that make the rules operational are defined.
It would also be normal to establish that domestic violence and rape in marriage are criminal offenses.
Furthermore, for Mexican society to change and reject violence against women, it is important that this issue becomes a primary issue of youth education in schools.
Madam President, the truth is that the first thing I would like to do tonight is to thank Mr. Skota for his excellent willingness to negotiate this report.
It has been a real pleasure to work with him and the other spokespersons of the parliamentary groups.

We are proud of the position that will be demonstrated tomorrow in the vote in this European Parliament, and we are proud of a position like this that defends quality, that bets on the development and valuation of rural areas, not only as.

Not merely as testimonies of a traditional European culture, but as true agents generating wealth and employment, employment that we are so lacking now in these times of economic crisis and dramatic employment levels in some member states.
We also like the defense that this European Parliament maintains and the position that the Agriculture Committee has already made clear, to bet on quality to the maximum degree.
And to the maximum extent, we are certainly committed to maintaining that differentiation between designations of origin and protected geographical indications.
Of course, we reject the idea of lowering quality and we want attention to be paid to and valued by Community production.
I welcome Commissioner Cholo's words.
Of course, it was nice to hear him talk about the commitment to the future of the European agricultural environment.
Of course, we hope that you will hear the voice of this Parliament, which will be made clear tomorrow in that vote.

And, finally, I would like to say that we hope that it will never happen again that the European Commission will get ahead of this Parliament by prohibiting things, such as, for example, the marketing standards for fruits and vegetables, which have done so much harm to free European competition.
We want market imbalances to be corrected and we also want to bet on quality, variety, food safety and the right amount of production.
We also want to defend the Community production and the quality of that Community agri-food production in the World Trade Organization.
And for that, we also count on the work of Commissioner Cholos, because neither our producers nor our European consumers can remain defenseless.
Mr. President, the Commissioner has spoken of the absurdity and obsolescence of the procedures.
Let us be consistent.
We have missed too many opportunities, too many treaties to introduce Community competence over European airspace.
But if we couldn't intervene as we should have done in heaven, then we could have done it on the skin of the earth.
For example, by monitoring the rights of passengers and also by mediating or calling for a truce in the various collective conflicts of land transport.
No minimum services, maximum services everywhere.
Madam President, when different and distant positions, such as those of Mauro, Gollnisch or Coleman, lead to the conclusion that.
The procedure, the electoral systems, the election of the MEPs presents problems. That means, Madam President, that we need a uniform electoral procedure.

It was a mandate that was already in the Treaties of Rome, and that is why the coordinators and I would like to take this opportunity to express my gratitude to everyone, but especially to Mr. Jauregui and Mr. Duff, we have agreed on an amendment
Tomorrow, we will vote, and I hope this House will support it, precisely so that we can resolve this issue, this issue of the uniform electoral procedure for the European Parliament elections, soon.
I think that would eliminate this type of question.
In his speech, Mr. Traskowski spoke about the necessary representativeness of this House, and this is a factor that most of the speakers, including Vice President Sefcovic, have highlighted.
I agree, and we say this in the report, article one, that the eighteen should enter into a block, because if they didn't, we would lose representation.

And in order for them to enter into a block, in order to fulfill that act of political justice, which is the Lisbon Agreement, we, Your Honor, have to be pragmatic, because a transitory and exceptional situation also requires transitory and exceptional solutions.
And that is why I do not hide it. I do not like the possibility that members of this House who have not left the 2009 elections will enter. I say this clearly in paragraph 2.

Let the eighteen come in or let's look for a pragmatic solution and let the eighteen come in and let's comply with the Lisbon Agreement, I ask this House and from there my report to opt for that transitional, pragmatic solution, but above all, Madam President, fair.
Thank you all for your collaboration and for the interesting contributions you have made to this work.

As I was unable to do so on the 11th of March, the International Day of the Victims of Terrorism, I would like to pay my respects from this Parliament today, and to acknowledge the enormous sacrifice of those who have paid the highest price in the name of freedom.

It is urgent to start working on a Directive that protects the rights of the victims of terrorism, who are always the great forgotten ones and who bear the humiliation of being unfairly equated with their executioners.
It is high time that these European institutions recognize the dignity of the victims of terrorism and help them in their right to protection and justice, and that it is soon translated into a law.

It will honor all those who make it possible, and the first article is that support for the victims of terrorism is the recognition of the right to justice and that no government ever pays a political price.

I call on all those who can defend the victims to never forget that true peace is born from justice, and that is the only one that we, from Europe and from anywhere in the world, must defend, those who believe in justice.

Mr. President, it has been necessary to face the abyss and economic collapse so that the heads of state and government have understood that the path is not that of more nationalism, but that of more Europe.
Measures adopted in this direction are circulating, such as the decline of the veto right in the European Council or the seed of a European public treasury.
Finally, although late, we have realized that we are all sailing in the same boat and that it is useless to deal with individual situations and, moreover, to do it in an improvised manner.

But I wonder if this attitude is a parenthesis or, on the contrary, the beginning of a true European economic government, because what is left over, dear colleagues, is governance and what is missing is genuine government, if we want to be faithful to the will of the founding fathers.

That is why, from this Parliament, we must promote all those reforms that are aimed at strengthening Europe and making budgetary and fiscal discipline a reality, forgetting, by the way, nostalgic sovereignties.
Colleagues, strengthening the European Commission and this Parliament is the only right recipe to build a Europe that would otherwise fade away like a fleeting shadow.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, from the INTA Committee, thank you, Mrs. de Sarnez, for the collaboration we have had.
Today more than ever, the Union for the Mediterranean, the strengthening of large projects and institutional development are necessary.
Today more than ever it is necessary to find solutions to the exit from the crisis, to research, to climate change, to water, to new energy models, to sustainable development.

And for this, it is necessary to promote and culminate trade and economic relations in the area, with short- and long-term measures, a free trade area, the removal of tariff barriers, and the opening of the north-south and south-south market.
The Barcelona Summit, the Spanish Presidency, will provide the possibility of a new commitment, a new situation, a new common commitment to democratization, economic and social solutions.
The Barcelona Summit can put us in a position to lead the Mediterranean.
Madam President, the Trans-European Transport Corridor includes the railway corridor called the Mediterranean Corridor.
It is a vital communication that will connect North Africa with Europe.
For Spain, it is vital because this axis is a priority, since it would connect Algeciras with Europe.
Not excluding other priority corridors, it would pass through Almería, Murcia, the Valencian Community and Catalonia.
And why, Commissioner Reding said, has greater economic activity and a high concentration of land transport.
This is one of the two conditions.
The possibility of communication with different ports in the Mediterranean area would be opened.
We need to take economic momentum and be competitive, as the Commissioner also said, because in this area more than fifty percent of Spanish exports are produced.
Therefore, if we increase the issue of a strategic railway axis across the Mediterranean, we will increase greater competitiveness for Spain and greater competitiveness for Europe.
Madam President, I would like to take this minute to congratulate the Spanish rotating presidency for the efforts it has made this semester to overcome the
A common position regarding Cuba and creating a new type of relationship between the European Union and Cuba, which naturally includes the defense of human rights as a priority issue.
This policy has not been crowned with success, mainly due to the intransigence of the Cuban dictatorship, which began this presidency in January.
This year, with the expulsion of the Member who speaks to you, when he was trying to visit the island with all the visas and all the legality to worry about human rights on it.
But that policy, that new policy that the Spanish government has undertaken, will yield results sooner or later.

Mr. President, Commissioner, colleagues, this is a regulation of utmost importance for consumers and the agri-food industry, because it is not at all easy to achieve a balanced labeling that contains everything essential, but is not so exhaustive that it complicates the information.
This is a great report and the rapporteur should be congratulated for it.
I agree with her on the major issues related to nutritional information and the controversial issue of profiles, especially if we take into account that the Commission did not comply with the
commitment to establish these profiles, as well as their conditions of use, before January 19, 2009, as prescribed by Regulation 1924/2006.

There is a topic that concerns me, and that is the possibility of national labelling standards coexisting, because it goes against the objective of the legislation, which is harmonization and avoiding all possible obstacles for a true single market to function.
As for the indication of the country of origin, the current legislation provides that this information must be provided when, in the event that it is not indicated, it may induce consumer deception.
In addition, there is always a voluntary labeling.
Going further can involve economic costs and administrative complexity for companies without bringing any clear significant benefits to the consumer.
And regarding the use of different languages, I have to say that the Commission's proposal coincides with the existing directive, which has worked well and has not raised any problems.
And reopening this debate may be dangerous and unnecessary and cause problems for the circulation of products.
Mr. President, the best example of the goodwill we have is the thousand amendments we are seeing from the Commission to the Plenary.

But, in addition to goodwill, I believe we must be practical when it comes to labeling food, if we do not want to achieve the opposite effect of what we are aiming for, that is, to confuse the consumer instead of helping him to inform himself.
It is not about illustrating, but about preventing, about informing them of what they can eat and to what extent.
Measure. It must be labeled on fat, sugar, and trans fats.
Indeed.
Indeed, about what affects cholesterol, about all those substances that affect, as we have said, obesity and people's health.

Yes, but some other foods with some other information, such as the place of origin, when it doesn't lead to confusion, or, for example, in a meat, saying the place of birth, the place of passage, the place of grazing, the place of sacrifice of the cattle, can illustrate a lot, but they will end up confusing.

It is up to us to be practical and for this regulation to be the one that will harmonize and inform consumers, or, otherwise, the one that will confuse more and impose issues that, far from achieving better health standards, will achieve greater degrees of confusion.

That is why I ask, for example, that some of us opt for the GDA, the daily intake, instead of the traffic lights, because it is very clear that if you consume this amount or twice as much, you will get fat, so consume only one.
The daily intake compared to other types of codes is what some of us are proposing, so as not to confuse the consumer any further.
Madam President, thank you very much, Mr. Martín Fraguero, for being here on behalf of the Spanish Presidency on a report like this, Commissioner.
Mr. Milana, congratulations on the ability to reach a common agreement and bring all interests together and put an initiative report on the table, one of the first initiative reports.
The deployment of aquaculture is important.

It is necessary due to the increase in fish consumption and the stagnation of fishing extraction capacity. But I want to highlight at this moment the economic importance of this activity, which generates economic wealth and employment.
Health guarantees are important, sustainability is important, and the protection of the marine environment is important.
The image of aquaculture must be promoted, and the scientific and research sectors must also be promoted.
Aquaculture is an opportunity, as Mr. Martín Fraguero said, within the CFP, as the Commissioner said.

A coherent framework for coordination must be given, and the possibility of regularization must be given, because aquaculture can provide sufficiency, sustainability, and economic resources, and I believe this is important for Europe.
Mr. President, in my opinion, this excellent report outlines the main lines that should inspire the new White Paper on Transport, which will shape European transport policy for the next ten years.

This report has several milestones worth mentioning: the need for a financial fund as a necessary instrument, the challenge of the growing demand for freight transportation, and the search for comfortable solutions that.

They provide safety for users and goods, the urgent need for sufficient and safe rest areas in road transport, and the diagnosis, in my opinion, that there should not be mere competition between the different countries.

The modes should not be complemented by each other, but by looking for efficiency criteria. The rapporteur's statement, which I believe is brave and fair, is that rail or sea transport is not always more environmentally friendly than road transport.
In short, the concept of efficient community is a concept of the future and, without a doubt, it must be supported, in my opinion, with all rigor.
Mr. President, this is a misconception.
Did you think you would really preside over Europe and influence the mechanisms that make the complex European machinery work?
He even believed, because he let people close to you proclaim it, that the world would live under his presidency a starry moment.
None of this has become a reality.
Let's get to some clarifications.

During these six months of the Spanish presidency, I would like to distinguish, on the one hand, between the political direction of the same and, on the other hand, the work of the officials who have been working in the machine rooms.
It is the first one that has failed, and this is due to the lack of adequate momentum from the Government Presidency, which has been woven more like a pendulum.
However, I would like to highlight the effort of the officials and their valuable willingness to serve Europe and Spain.
And, Mr. President, Spain has magnificent professional officials, and if there is one thing to regret, it is that they are marginalized too much in everyday reality.
That said, it is appropriate to acknowledge that some commendable initiatives have been adopted in these six months.
Among them, I am pleased to mention the organ donation and transplantation plan and the treatment given to patients'rights in cross-border healthcare.
More in the air have been left the agreements on the new strategy two thousand twenty and, above all, those related to the European External Action Service, both of which are still too fragile.
What has happened with the European Protection Order for Victims of Gender Violence has been regrettable, and the same gloomy result has been offered by the European Union.
The Community patent is essential for the lives of thousands of companies and is blocked in part by the language problems that Spanish legislation stimulates.

But all the major political actions have ended in a spectacular failure, from the Mediterranean summit to the European Union's summit with the United States, and I quote the latter, regarding which its own government was responsible for creating excessive expectations.
However, we must agree that not being able to carry out their policy regarding Cuba has been highly positive for the Cubans.
Finally, the progress made on the path to better European economic governance cannot in any way be attributed to your Presidency, which is blatantly absent in the most relevant issues.
Goodbye to the Spanish Presidency.

I would like to draw a positive conclusion from this experience: my fantasy of a convinced Europeanist is excited by the thought that it could mean the end of the rotating presidencies, as they have been conceived until now.

Would this be good news? Because as long as Europe does not strengthen its common institutions, solidly uniting its fragments, it will continue to run the risk of being sunk in the empty spaces of irrelevance.
Mr. President, believe me, Mr. Zapatero, I would have liked to give a different speech today.
Your Honor, you have set a semester full of ambition and set the bar so high in your claims that, compared to what has actually been achieved, disappointment is inevitable.
The truth is that Your Honor has not been able to overcome a complex situation that required leadership and credibility.
Your Honor has once recalled that the European Union is a club with rules, and I agree.
But it was your honor to demand compliance with those rules.
The reality is that it was the Spanish government that was being urged to fulfill its obligations.
In this picture, positive achievements that have not been lacking have been clarified.
Your Honor has had time to tell them, I haven't.
Democracy, ladies and gentlemen, is a regime of public opinion.
And that is what it seems. Obama's disdain, the cancellation of the Mediterranean Summit and the announced European Union-United States Summit constitute major failures.
The haste to close improvised agreements at any cost has not favored the image of the Spanish administration, and the way to achieve some respectable goal has been described as a sloppy one.
Spain is a great nation and will remain so, despite the poor management of this time.
Our diplomats and officials have maintained the pace and, thanks to this, Spain's prestige will continue.
The truth is that the value judgment that will be made of this Presidency will weigh more on the situation in Spain than what has been done or not done here.
It was hardly possible to lead such a difficult company, who has placed his country in a stage of uncertainty and unease.
In the best case, this Presidency has been sadly irrelevant.
Thank you very much, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. In the coming months, we will dive right into the debate on the new CAP.

It is important to reach a good agreement, so I hope that the Belgian Presidency will achieve what the Spanish Presidency has not achieved, that is, to channel the discussions in such a way that the Member States commit to maintaining a policy in the future.

A truly strong common agricultural policy, with a sufficient budget to meet the needs of the twenty-seven new and old member states, and not to happen like in two thousand and five, when there was a lack of money and modulation had to be invented.

In the next CAP reform, we are risking the viability of a sector that not only provides intangible goods and services such as environmental care, but should also ensure the supply of food to European citizens.

We have already witnessed painful situations of shortage in the past, so it is necessary that the European Parliament provides security of supply based on Community production as the main objective of the next reform, without leaving aside other contributions such as the fight against climate change.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, I agree with Commissioner Cholos that this report is necessary, very necessary, and it comes at a good time, because the abuses committed by large retailers have been demonstrated, severely distorting the different links in the food chain.

The Bové report, which at some point may go too far by trying to be too interventionist, must be recognized from a social market economy perspective, as we advocate from the European People's Party, and I say that it must be recognized because it collects answers to the fair claims of European producers.

In addition, it provides transparency to the different parts of the food chain, which is always good, and gives many more possibilities and support to defend the weakest sectors of that chain, and certainly supports European consumers so that they know more about that chain.

The European food industry could have been taken into account more within this report, perhaps, and it would have been very good, but this report also includes measures to curb price volatility, and that was very necessary.

Measures are also being taken to give equity to those links in the chain, as requested in the Environment Committee, and they also call for the fight against abusive and unfair practices of large-scale distribution.
And it is high time to establish a list of abusive practices and for European legislation to prohibit them definitively.
It is also important that measures are taken to prevent difficult practices through white marks that go against competition and against the intellectual property law.

For all these reasons, we must support the Bové report and we must support all colleagues who, from the different parliamentary committees INCO, ENVI or Agriculture, have shown that they have worked hard so that this report finally comes to light and helps European producers to move forward.
The alarm bell rings and it is true.
And frustration also sounds, as is being heard in the speeches of this plenary, for not having achieved the Millennium Goals.
And the truth is that what we are risking is a lot.

Our natural environment is so fragile that if one day the big fish decided that it would not continue to eat the small one, we would have to pay for it all from the generational pocket with our health and well-being as a currency of exchange.
The European Union is a leader today in the fight against climate change and has been for a while in pioneering conservation measures.

But, as the unfulfilled objectives show, it seems as if there was a lack of will, not only for implementation and coordination, which has also been mentioned here, but also for expansion, to go beyond our very delimited special conservation areas.
Of course, biodiversity is not a museum piece that can be locked in a ghetto area, as it sometimes seems to be done, taking a look at it from time to time.
Biodiversity lives and has no borders, it crosses the entire Earth with a domino effect in which if one piece falls, all the others fall.

And I draw attention to the need for a global and more community-based will, especially with regard to the soil, because subsidiarity as the only method for managing the soil or forests can be one of the new fearsome enemies of biodiversity.

That is why I draw attention to paragraph 67 and the possible vote that will take place, and I ask you to reject the second part, because I am convinced that a common policy on soils would help to conserve the entire territory.

European, so varied, so diverse for better and for worse, and so lacking in political will by the States, and so in need of an increasingly European Union, with all the extension of the word, which means more Union also for the soil.

Mr. President and Commissioner, first of all I would like to highlight the work of the rapporteur, Mrs. Macaban, not only in substance but also in form, because she has done so in collaboration with all the shadow rapporteurs.
I would also like to thank the experts of the Spanish Administration for their contribution to this Agreement.

The purpose of this European Union pharmacovigilance system is to strengthen the monitoring, transparency and communication of the safety of medicines once they are marketed, especially with regard to their risk profiles and adverse reactions that may occur.

It is worth noting the creation of the European Pharmacovigilance Committee, which will evaluate and issue recommendations to the European Medicines Agency on safety issues that may arise with medicines marketed in the European Union.

The solution reached for the notification to eudravigilance of suspicions of adverse reactions, both by the Member States and by those responsible for the marketing of the medicines, is very important.

Eudravigilance will be the only source of information, but at the same time, the competent authority of the Member State where the adverse reaction is suspected to have occurred will be informed, and this is very important.
It is also worth highlighting the possibility that is opened to consumers to be able to communicate any adverse reaction and, in this sense, the creation and management by the Agency of a portal.
The European Medicines Safety Agency, which in turn links to the portals of each member state, will help improve citizens'knowledge of the safety of the medicines they consume.
And, finally, we cannot forget that, since pharmacovigilance plays a fundamental role in the protection of public health, the approval of the Directive and the
This directive and regulation will contribute significantly to this, improving not only the current procedures, but also the coordination of actions between the different member states.

Mr. President, I appreciate the rapporteur's effort to accept some suggestions and, of course, his defense of copyright, which I share. But the inclusion of the infringing and punishable nature of certain exchanges and the.

The recognition of the sanctioning authority of suppliers, as well as the exclusion of mass exchanges as a possible infringement in the alternative resolution, make it impossible to vote in favor of either of the two reports in the race.
The Galló report has generated great interest and could have been timely, but the substance of the debate is too much focused on the debate for or against the French law called.
Dopi, cut off Internet connection for offenders, without there having been a genuine European debate that takes into account the reality of other progress in national legislations.

I hope we will reach a common position in the Socialist Group and a majority in the European Parliament in the debates and amendments on the Commission's proposal for a directive, which will soon reach the Parliament, as announced by Commissioner Barnier.
On that occasion, we will try to reach a more balanced position than today, which takes into account both the rights of Internet users and the essential respect for intellectual property.
Mr. President, I congratulate those who have worked on this report, on this financial package, especially the officials and the members of this Parliament.
A huge financial crisis had to occur for Europe to wake up.
However, an opportunity has been lost, in part, to strengthen the common institutions of Europe, because, on the one hand, these new supervisory authorities have a scope of competence

It is limited in the face of similar authorities of member states and it is a pity, furthermore, that no progress has been made in a similar integration to the one that occurred with the central bank system.
We have made progress, but we need to keep climbing the mountain.

Mr. President, as a member of the Human Rights Commission, as a Spanish and European citizen, and as a victim of terrorism since the terrorist organization ETA murdered my brother and his wife in Seville, I am addressing this Parliament to denounce the Venezuelan government and its president for allowing terrorists from

They train on Venezuelan soil, at the orders of the alleged terrorist Cubillas, who works for the government of Hugo Chavez, despite the fact that an international search and capture order is imposed on him, which is a serious violation of the fundamental right to the safety of any European citizen.
I demand that the Spanish government take decisive action in the face of this serious humiliation of all Spaniards.
Zapatero cannot remain silent while the Venezuelan ambassador calls our civil guards, who have been and will be an example of courage in the fight against ETA, torture.
Nor can it look the other way in the face of this growing cooperation between ETA and the FARC on Venezuelan soil, as Judge Eloy Velasco has already denounced.
Zapatero cannot shake hands with a leader like Chavez, who is turning Venezuela into a terrorist refuge.

The president of a country like Spain, where terrorism has caused so much pain, cannot continue to ignore this problem and should give an answer that he deserves and that any ordinary citizen would give if they had the opportunity to do so.
On February 14, 2008, as a Valentine's Day gift, the Conference of Presidents decided that intergroup meetings would only take place on Thursdays.
Since then we have tried to resolve this issue.
We haven't achieved it.
Mr. President, the intergroups must meet today on a date that is not appropriate.
They almost never have rooms and never have interpretation.

Today I speak not only as the president of the Intergroup on Poverty and Human Rights, but also with the mandate of most of the intergroups in this House, therefore of the members of this House who are part of those intergroups.
And I solemnly ask that the Conference of Presidents reconsider and annul the decision of February 14, 2008 and return to the previous situation of freedom of intergroups.
And if you don't, I also kindly say that we will bring the matter to the plenary of this House and it will be decided who is sovereign in this House, which is this Parliament.
Mr. President, the International Day against Trafficking and the Trafficking of People for the purpose of Social Exploitation has highlighted some data that should make us act as a replica.
More than ninety percent of prostitution in Europe comes from blackmail and extortion.

And in the face of these data, we should ask ourselves if we are doing everything necessary to protect the dignity and integrity of thousands of women whose rights are also protected by the Fundamental Charter that we approved with the Treaty of Lisbon.
Because we are not talking about the oldest trade in the world, but about the only form of slavery that we have not been able to eradicate from old Europe.
Countries like Spain are making significant efforts in this direction, pursuing traffickers, raising public awareness and promoting reservation plans for women victims.
But it is not enough.
Europe must be a single space of action and commitment.

The next Treatment Directive is an opportunity to act on demand through pedagogy and to make it easier to access, for example, the offer to advertise in all types of media, in addition to increasing bilateral cooperation with third states to fight this scourge from the beginning.
We have an opportunity to
I draw the attention of this Parliament to continue being at the forefront of citizens'rights.
Madam President, we all agree that the foreign service is a historic opportunity for European construction.

But for this, it is necessary to act with great foresight, because this is not the time for internal struggles over resources that are exceeded or retained in the short term, and wars between the different European institutions.
What is appropriate now, on the contrary, is to have a general vision of what the European Union should be in the world, that is, to do just the opposite of what
What happened a few days ago, on the occasion of the Nobel Peace Prize awarding, where too many voices from Europe were heard, and not all of them were brave.
One of the exceptions is that the President of this Parliament, Mr. Buzek, is the author of a brilliant and worthy statement.

Mr. President, the regulation we are debating today is of vital importance for the future of a sector, the cutting and similar industries, which in my region, the land of Don Quixote, specifically in Albacete, represents, in addition to the survival of more than eight zero jobs, an element of identity and a commitment to the future of craftsmanship as a source of employment.

And the Maidin seal on the knives has been reclaimed for a long time by social groups such as Aprecu and fought by the Government of Castilla-La Mancha with the unanimous support of its regional Parliament.
A seal of origin that is not interventionism, it is a commitment to transparency, commercial rules of the game and the fight against unfair competition.

It is to increase the decision-making capacity of consumers when choosing a product so that they take into account not only the final price of it, but also the quality mark of the place of origin or the social conditions in which it is produced.

And, above all, it will be a new horizon of optimism for many people who are having a hard time, but who today look at us thinking that we have not been indifferent when it comes to betting on fairer trade, yes, but also for giving added value to those who, in addition to producing, do so with respect for social rights and the best conditions of European workers.
That is why I thank the opponent and Mr. Menéndez del Valle for their political support and social awareness on this important issue for my land.
Mr. President, let me see if I can calm down a bit in this lively debate.
It is regrettable that some countries and some states that make up the European Union are still present in this G20 forum.
Despite this anomaly, which certainly weakens Europe's image in the world, it would be good if there was at least a common global position in that global forum.
And what would be, in my opinion, that common position?

In my humble opinion, I believe that, firstly, the adoption of a global agreement to address the consequences of the crisis cannot be delayed, and not just a financial agreement. Secondly, Europe must maintain the euro as a reference currency or, if preferred, as an anchor for

To prevent market turbulence from dragging us along and making us repeat the mistakes made over the 20th century. Thirdly, the euro must serve as a herald of what Europe must represent in the world of democratic values and freedoms.
public
In summary, it is necessary to know that in the global world, in this global game, the one who only plays national cards loses.
Mr. President, Commissioner, Honorable Members, I believe we are in the process of congratulating the rapporteur, Mrs. Meissner.
There were different positions, and she has obtained compromise solutions that allow us to all be together on an important issue.

Honorable members, the Transport Committee has decided that all bars should be protected in a similar way, and to do this, it invokes that if this were not the case, a situation of unfair competition would occur.

We accept the majority's position in favor of a legal situation with uniform rules for the entire Union, but I will not spare the honourable Members the opportunity to clearly point out that this also implies a certain lack of fairness.
It is clear that the Baltic Sea, the North Sea and the English Channel are more polluted areas and that the controls of the sulfur limit values will have to be more rigorous in their case.
The measures related to ports must be positively evaluated, as they affect solutions to reduce transportation times and handling costs.
In any case, I will not tire of reiterating that at this point we have an outstanding issue.
If ports are not decisively liberalized, they will not be able to expand the central role they must have in the context of comodality.
Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the promotion of a strategy aimed at modifying the specific repercussions of climate change.
I think this is a positive report that should be voted on.
But we cannot forget that it occurs in the context of a serious disaster, which is that of the Gulf of Mexico.

In this regard, the Commission is urged to assess whether the framework for the revision of the European Maritime Safety Agency Regulation strengthens the role that the Agency must play in inspections, prevention and subsequent cleaning tasks of hydrocarbon spill.
My personal opinion, Commissioner, is that yes, and that these tasks must be strengthened with the mandate that is required for this purpose.
Thank you, Mr. President. The integrated maritime policy is a transversal, regional and sectoral policy, which includes fisheries and agriculture, and it should not be subordinated to other policies.
We all have to respond to environmental and economic problems, both to society in general and to the fishing sector. New technologies, fishing gear, species development, a maritime economy plan.

To create more and better employment, quality supplies, international relations that prevent piracy, and to promote the governance of our seas that do not have barriers and do not have sustainability problems, as in the case of Iceland.
This would be working for an integrated maritime policy, this would be working for the environment and sustainability.
Mr. President, the Our Lady of Socorro Church was recently attacked in Baghdad, and fifty-eight people were murdered, mostly women and children, for the sole reason of being Christians.
Al-Qaeda has proudly assumed the authorship of the hazard.
It is not an isolated fact, but the culmination of persecution and attacks on Christians in countries with a Muslim majority.
Expulsions in Morocco, threats in Turkey, attacks in India or Nigeria.
In January, six Christians were massacred at the door of a church in Cairo.
Cairo. How long will the complicit silence of Western democracies last?
Fortunately, President Busek has made an institutional statement.
The statement of condemnation of the High Representative, Mrs. Ashton, has been limited to a condemnation of a terrorist act.
terrorist. Why is the mobile phone not mentioned? The condition of Christians, which is the unequivocal cause of the massacre.
I haven't heard anything from Mr. Zapatero, I haven't heard anything from President Erdogan.
Erdogan, what is the purpose of the alliance of civilizations?
I feel sorry for our papanateism and our cowardice.

Inevitably, I remember the mournful and misunderstood Ariana Falachi, who announced the arrival of Eurabia and was almost stoned for having the courage to denounce what is happening in the complex Europe.
Thank you also to the Commissioner. I share the desire of this House.
I want the proposals of the Europeans to get the support they deserve in Cancun.
In relation to this debate, it is necessary to emphasize the importance of cities in the preservation of the environment.

There is a pact between more than one thousand mayors of the European Union that demonstrates the existence of recognition of the problem by these authorities, whose actions are decisive if we want to be successful.
The big words we use are worthless if we don't have the collaboration of the mayors of the cities.
For this, it is very important that emissions are disclosed, as cities produce almost eighty percent of greenhouse gases.
Today, there is no such disclosure, or worse, a common pattern for the measurement of these emissions itself.
There is a non-profit organization called the CO2 dissemination project, which already receives information from thousands of companies and I think it could also be used by municipalities.
Without their contribution, without the contribution of these municipalities and mayors, environmental action remains in smoke, the smoke from which we want to escape.

Mr. President, some have said that the condemnation of Morocco is too mild given the magnitude of the repression of human rights in the Sahara, where Morocco is nothing more than an occupying country without any sovereignty or legal title.
But the important thing is the message that the whole of Europe and this Parliament can no longer stand their violence.
Yesterday I spoke about the Hague Tribunal in this very Parliament.

The international community, which sadly failed to prevent the genocide in Rwanda, Yugoslavia and Darfur, I hope will prevent the genocide in Western Sahara, and we will not have to see it before another court, also in The Hague, as I said, but this time for war crimes.
Mr. President, Commissioner, the Directive approved in 2009 was a success because it updates the regulatory framework that has been regulating the safety of toys.
It is a big step in the right direction because it shows us the way forward, but it is not enough.
We must always be vigilant and attentive to ensure that the toys that are marketed do not endanger the safety and health of children.
All toys on the market must comply with current legislation.
We must review and improve the surveillance mechanisms to detect dangerous toys, whether it is due to toxic substances, ECMR, or fragrances and other dangerous substances, such as HPA compounds.
It is necessary that the rules to be followed are clearer regarding the warning about the minimum age and the dangers derived from improper use.
The recommended age for toys must be based on studies of the child's behavior.
We have to be able to adapt our regulations to scientific advances based on solid studies and be more rigorous in market surveillance and toy imports.
It is necessary to work together and strengthen cooperation between the member states, and to have the joint work of customs to control the route of imported toys.
Citizens are willing to make their Christmas purchases and we must give them the security that the products they buy meet all safety requirements.
I think that in this debate we have seen clearly that we all agree to support the objective of this report.
The different political groups have shown their support for this Directive, which offers greater protection to the victims.
Therefore, I wonder what impediment exists in approving this instrument?
I repeat, what fears are there for something as necessary and simple as protecting victims equally throughout Europe to finally become a reality?
Hoping that this Parliament will approve this report by a majority, I turn to the Council and the Commission, reminding them that we have
We have overcome the legal obstacles in our negotiations and I applaud that the Commission recognizes our work as we recognize what it will do in the future.

We do not have to exclude ourselves, but rather help each other by approving today this more specific instrument, tomorrow the broader package of measures to help the victims that the Commission will present and with which I am committed to collaborating.
Therefore, let us be brave and responsible today and help all those who have the right to live in a safer Europe.
Let's help everyone, I repeat, whether they are men, women or children.
Let us help those who look to us today to give them a better life, a life that will give them back their freedom, their security and, above all, their dignity.

Madam President, the Group of the European People's Party will vote enthusiastically on this report, and I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs, the Commission and the Council on this agreement.
We coined, ladies and gentlemen, in the 1980s the term democratic deficit.
With him, we wanted to say that in the European Union, decisions were made only by the Council of Ministers on the proposal of the Commission, and this Parliament was only consulted.
The battle of this Parliament since the 1980s, through the Maastricht Treaty, Amsterdam, Nice, the Constitutional Treaty, and the Treaty of Lisbon, has been

To fill that democratic deficit, and I believe that with the Treaty of Lisbon, with the new powers of the European Parliament, with the participation of the national parliaments, we have achieved that goal.
And we are rounding it off today with this citizen initiative, which was due, in the work of the convention, to the good cooperation between national parliaments and the European Parliament.

And I would like to recall here the names of Jürgen Mayer, our German social democrat colleague, and Alain Lamassoure, who were the ones who brought that initiative to the plenary of the Convention and made it approved.
Therefore, I believe we have completed the circle, Madam President.
I believe that today, when we vote on the initiative, we will have put on the table the Act on the Death of the Democratic Deficit Concept.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is our turn to act responsibly, and today we also have the opportunity to do so.
By voting on the Union budget, we will fulfill what is expected of us: a responsible Parliament and a co-decision-making Parliament.
I think it is a good day for Europe, ladies and gentlemen.

Mr. President, in January 2012, four hundred Spanish egg producers could disappear, about thirty percent of the total in my country, with the loss of a production of three hundred thousand tons of eggs.

And the European Union could stop producing those eighty million eggs, those two million tons, and we would only be able to cover them with imports from third countries whose animal welfare standards are much lower than those of the European Union if we do not act very intelligently.
This 1999 Directive, which requires the increase of the space of laying hen cages, requires us to act with intelligence and a possibilistic vision, because if we don't.
We will only weaken European production and give extra commercial opportunities to third countries where the space for birds is infinitely worse than the current one we have in the European Union.

It is a directive that requires a lot of effort from European producers. In Spain alone, we can understand that the cost is raised to about six hundred million euros, but we must not forget that it also has an economic impact that extends to the wolf product industry and the food industry in general.

I therefore ask for the support of the honourable Members for the amendment of the Popular Group to the second paragraph, which calls for a solution to be sought at least for the responsible farms of responsible industrialists who are proceeding to the transformation of their farms and who will be almost finishing in January 2012.

We must support them in transforming these facilities and give them time to complete this process, thus avoiding irreparable damage to farms and preventing a situation of shortage in the Community market from arising overnight, consequently increasing consumer prices.
It is about respecting the Directive, giving an opportunity to the egg and egg industry, while also respecting the right to animal welfare and the right of consumers to a reasonable price.

Mr. President, I believe it is fair to thank the rapporteurs, especially Mrs. Grostet and Mrs. Dagmar Ronberend from my own group, for the work they have done to bring a rule out of the stagnation and make it useful, because that work has allowed the right to public health to be included as a legal basis.

and to have a new orientation that allows us to lay the foundations that must guarantee citizens the safety and quality they choose at all times, especially because it also allows us to clearly regulate the role of the States, both of the countries of origin that have to make the payment and those in which treatment is received.

But I believe that we should not feel satisfied just because of that, but that this has to be the beginning of a much greater progress that makes, as Mrs. Romperen said, this directive a mere process, because the level of equality achieved in all States makes the movements of each citizen to each country unnecessary.

And in this fight we must obtain a rule that guarantees more the right of citizens in relation to the attention they have to receive, benefits, accessibility and security than the mere right they already have to mobility between States.
Equality is what the Union will do, and if not, we will be taking very small steps.
Madam President, the Spanish Socialist delegation voted in favour, like the rest of our group, but I would not leave without expressing my concern, because they have been included in this directive.
The issue of organ transplants, against the criterion of the Environment Committee, as a result of the Council's persistent insistence on including transplants in this Directive.

I hope that this inclusion does not diminish the effectiveness of the good legislation that we approved in this very plenary session, both with the Directive on Transplants and with the Action Plan, very recently and with almost all the support.

And I warn that we will be vigilant that this inclusion does not diminish the good work done by organizations as successful as the National Transplant Organization of Spain and, of course, with the intention of saving twenty zero lives that we had both in the Transplant Directive and in the Action Plan that, I repeat, we approved here.
Therefore, I make it clear and say that we will continue to monitor compliance with this Directive in this regard.
Mr. President, today is also the European Day against Sexual Health.
Honorable members, the data is worrying. The World Health Organization estimates that more than three hundred million people involuntarily contract a sexually transmitted disease every year.

In Europe, as the European Sexual Health Forum warns, the increase in the number of unwanted pregnancies among teenagers is worrying due to an excessive deficit of education and training among our young people.

Even, as the Commission points out, there are different and diverse inequalities in Europe in access to sexual health services depending on the States and, within these, depending on the level of income of the citizens.
To combat all of this, a European strategy is needed.
Only five member states have plans in this regard, but in all of them, the number of unwanted pregnancies, sexually transmitted diseases, and the number of abortions have been reduced.

A common strategy that focuses on prevention from the educational sphere, that expands information policies, that increases efforts in family planning and facilitates accessibility in contraceptive methods.
A transversal and ambitious strategy, free of taboos, to guarantee the rights of all citizens to sexual health in the highest safety and health conditions.
Mr. President, at a time of strong social tensions, we can only enthusiastically welcome the great social agreement in Spain between the government, the unions and the employers.
This agreement is exemplary for Europe, where no such milestones have been produced for a long time.
Taking into account the reasoning of Cándido Méndez, one of the main protagonists of the Spanish pact, who attended the meeting of the Economic and Social Council in Brussels on Tuesday, February 8.
Cándido then insisted on the need to extend the consultation at a European level and on the need to have the voice and initiative of the unions in this Europe of ours.
This is how it should be.

Mr. President, saving distances in the matter of terrorism and immigration, I have noticed that the European Union unfortunately moves in the face of emergency situations, such as the one of a serious.

An attack or a massive landing of immigrants, like the one currently taking place in Lampedusa, where the exodus of citizens from Tunisia towards the Italian coasts can lead to a chronicle of a death announced.
The journey of hope can end in a cursed journey and will weigh on our consciences, on those of all those who witness these continuous uncontrolled flows and do not say enough with enough authority.
When it happens, we will put our hands on our heads, but the next day we will forget.

European citizens have the obligation and the right to know the truth that the Mediterranean strategy does not work, that the common migration policy will remain a dream as long as European countries do not commit to sufficient economic means for Frontex to be effective.
Talking doesn't cost anything, but we have to act.
Do you really think that Frontex can currently guarantee the security of European borders?
I don't think so.

And let us hope that the citizens of Tunisia, Egypt and other Maghreb countries do not decide to seek a better future in Europe in large numbers and do so in their countries, because that is what they have fought for and we must contribute to helping them.
Therefore, solidarity, responsibility, but above all, truth when it comes to talking about a common European migration policy, which is more necessary today than ever.

Madam President, it has already been said that the backbone of pension systems in Europe is and must continue to be the public system, because this is the only system that guarantees cohesion and the only one that also reduces the risks of poverty in our society.

It is still striking that in OECD countries the highest rates of equity in citizens'income are given in terms of pensions, or that, due to the crisis, private pensions lost only twenty percent of their value in 2008 and are still far from the required solvency levels.

All this shows that, at a time of inescapable reforms, the sustainability of our pension system must be done in a transversal manner, taking into account, among other factors, ambitious policies on birth rates or work-life balance.
Ambitious policies for access and employment, or even immigration policies based on integration, which also guarantees, from a demographic point of view, the sustainability of our pensions.
Finally, I regret that the text does not set limits on the abuse of the status of scholarships in companies, as, as a general rule, they are excluded from all types of social contributions.
In my opinion, this is essential for a whole new generation of workers, who, if they are being required to have a dignified pension, would also need to be punished less to access decent work.

Mr. President, Commissioner, we are at a key moment in the construction of the future cohesion policy, which, after the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, focuses not only on economic and social aspects, but also on territorial ones.
Territorial cohesion pursues harmonious development between territories to ensure that its citizens can make the most of their territorial uniqueness.
