But to achieve this goal, it is also necessary to make progress in the area of cooperation between the regions of the Union that face the same challenges and problems.

This is the objective of the European Union's strategy for the Atlantic region, a common perspective to address the common challenges faced by the states of the region, including marine research, maritime surveillance, and environmental and economic challenges.

To achieve our goals, it is necessary to adopt an integrated strategic approach that is in line with the 2020 Strategy and the European Union's policies for the period after 2013, especially with regional policy and maritime policy.
But, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, it is necessary that this strategy is based on a renewed multilevel governance, based on closer participation of public authorities.
regional and local authorities, member states, the European Union, and stakeholders from the private sector and civil society organizations, including interregional organizations and networks.

It is a very significant day to talk about equality between men and women, because we celebrate Women's Day, remembering those who fought for labor and economic rights and for women's voting one hundred years ago.
We have made a lot of progress in these hundred years, but there is still a lot to be done, and true equality is still a dream, and discrimination against women is a reality.

I believe that each of us, men and women, can do much more to achieve the true emancipation of women, because there are many women in the world who have their right to live threatened, their dignity violated and their freedom denied.
Allow me, on this Women's Day, to show my support and hope to all the women who are fighting for their democratic rights in the North African Revolution.
Because a woman cannot be worth half of a man, neither in Arab countries nor anywhere else in the world.
Therefore, we are worth the same and we deserve the same.
And I will continue to fight to achieve it, and as long as there is no equality, Women's Day will continue to exist.
Although there are many who do not want to see it, it is a reality that there are women who earn half as much as men, and domestic violence affects women and children above all.
And I repeat, we must continue to denounce all these facts in this Parliament and, of course, I promise that I will continue to work.
Mr. President, I would like to express my satisfaction with the opinion of the Members who have spoken here this morning and who insist on respect for Parliament and the Commission.
Therefore, my modest vote in favor will depend on the European Council being willing to accept the role of the mentioned institutions.
because the new mechanism we are talking about must be an important component of economic governance led by the European Union
able to ensure coherence between the common economic policy, which must set clear, precise and limited objectives, and this stability instrument.

That is to say, we must avoid at all costs that this effort we are embarking on ends up on the intergovernmental path, which is a dead path or the path of the dominance of a few states, because all of this would frustrate the reform.
Dear colleagues, Europe is built stone by stone, and this is one of those that reinforce and balance this delicate building.
There are still essential points to be improved, so we have to send the report back to the Commission.
The parliamentary process of this report does not end here.
The initial proposal was bad.
This is what consumer associations at national and European level told us.
And, in particular, I appreciate the work of the Consumers'Union of Asturias and its President, the tireless Dafi Alonso.
We have managed to reject the general principle of maximum harmonization of the old article four.

It must be said loudly that maximum harmonization, by establishing the same protection in all member states, would mean a reduction in the protection of many consumers, as there is a greater tradition in various countries in the protection of consumer rights.

I would like to emphasize, in any case, that it is essential to ensure that the list of abusive contractual clauses is not exhaustive, so that each Member State can increase the number of clauses it considers unacceptable and invalid in contracts with consumers.

Invest the burden of proof in the individual clauses, so that it is the merchants who have to prove that the clauses have been negotiated individually, that they move away from what is generally established, that the contractual clauses must be expressed in a clear and understandable way.
We are still against the establishment of maximum harmonization with regard to abusive clauses.
The Eurobarometer indicates that 79% of traders believe that full harmonization in this field will have little or no effect on their activities abroad.
Mr. President, Commissioner, allow me, first of all, to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Schwab, and Mrs. Gerhardt for the excellent work done.
and a general reflection.
It is not about increasing protectionism, but about not cutting existing rights in some of the member states.
Because if we want and pursue to establish a genuine internal market for relations between companies and consumers, we must
To establish a balance between the high level of consumer rights protection and the defense of the competitiveness of companies.
This balance involves agreeing on minimum harmonization and the possibility of allowing member states to maintain or adopt additional regulations that improve consumer protection.
We cannot allow the adoption of a community standard to mean the lack of protection for many consumers and users.
I am pleased that the negotiations in the European Parliament have improved, but I would like to insist that the rights that have already been established are not cut.

Mr. President, many experts are telling us that the next crisis may be energy-related and that, in addition, we are either not doing the necessary homework to avoid it or we are not doing it at the necessary speed to avoid it.
Next Saturday, the World Nature Forum calls for us all to make a small gesture in favor of sustainability.
Many citizens will turn off the light for an hour and many public administrations will follow them.
But it is not enough.
Europe cannot continue to depend on energy that is not its own, that is far away, or on insecure energy.
We have to help the States build a new energy model in which renewable energies are the heart of the new.
And we also have to support the awareness of new consumption patterns, because without a doubt renewables and efficiency are the keys to future sustainability.

Finally, I would like to call on all the countries of the Union to join this call, this will of five of them, including Spain, to increase the reduction of CO2 emissions by up to thirty percent, because in this way we would demonstrate that Europe, in addition to being a vanguard in freedom and rights, is also a vanguard in its commitment to the sustainability of the planet.
Madam President, the majority of the times I have spoken in this Parliament I have done so to denounce violence against women and I am here again to fight it.

I must say that I not only do not tire of it, but I also consider it essential to continue speaking publicly about this violation of human rights, since there is no cause that can be defended without a sounding board, and this Parliament is the best.

I have a voice at my disposal to defend all those women who suffer daily abuse and who need us, legislators, to force states to punish the aggressors according to the severity of the crime and also to help the victims.

When it is estimated that a quarter of European women have suffered gender violence at least once in their lives and that children have suffered the same, I believe it is impossible not to demand a greater commitment, such as the one recognized by the Commission in its action plan.

I believe it is necessary to keep insisting over and over again on protecting the victims, as we have already done with the European Protection Order for Victims, for which I was rapporteur, and which I hope will become a reality as soon as possible.

This report has had a great consensus and support from the beginning, which shows that when it comes to addressing domestic violence, which affects all members of the family, it is a problem that has been a problem that has been a problem for many years.
Families, children, elderly people, women and men should not be a reason for political opportunism, as it is our honor to all to make progress in solving this social scourge.

The first thing is not to remain silent, and the second thing is to get to work, because although we have been talking about gender violence for decades, we have not been able to reduce the number of deaths.

We will be doing something wrong, and therefore it is time to forget about demagogy and to move from words to actions, providing more help and the necessary reaction so that women can live with dignity and security.
security, so that all the victims know that I will always be here to lend my voice until we all manage to defeat this
A terrible enemy that sadly ends the lives of so many innocents. I say enough, enough already, and I ask all of you to say the same with me.
Mr. President, thank you very much, Commissioner. I agree with you that we must listen to the citizens and regain confidence in the European project.
That is why today could be a great day for Europe and European social construction.

Because with the approval of these reports, we are not only moving towards the reactivation of the single market, a key element in the face of the current economic crisis, but we are also responding to the demands of citizens who are asking for more Europe and strengthening social rights.
Europe must respond to the new global challenges and make the European economy a highly competitive social market economy that creates sustainable growth with more and better employment.

But this objective must be based on the insertion of a social clause in all legislation related to the internal market, which puts citizens at the center of our attention and priority, and strengthens their social rights.
Finally, I would like to ask the Commission to present these proposals as soon as possible.
Mr. President, the blue tongue has been a constant threat to our livestock and, with it, to our public health.

A disease we fought against through the activated vaccine, whose use involves the creation of restricted areas for the circulation of animals, because the use of these vaccines can cause unwanted circulation of the virus in uninfected animals.

For these reasons, the use of the vaccine was limited to those areas where infected animals had been found before, creating double harm for the farmers, on the one hand, the disease and, on the other hand, the restrictions.

But all these problems seem to be avoided through the new inactivated vaccine, which, in addition to avoiding the disturbances that can be caused in the domestic livestock market, allows the development of new and broader strategies, which is the truly important thing, of prevention in the fight against this disease.
For all these reasons, it is of vital importance for this sector that we modify the Directive to allow its use, and that we do so as soon as possible.

Honorable members, compliance with what our treaties provide, especially with regard to correlation tables, cannot be an excuse for this regulation not to come into force before the summer, because with our delay, with your delay, we would only be harming the farmers.

Mr. President, first of all, I would like to thank the Committee on Petitions for the work it has done following the complaint filed by FEPEX, which is the Spanish organization of fruit and vegetable producers and exporters, based on the report published in 2007 by OLAF, the Union's Anti-Fraud Agency.

I believe that the conclusions of this report are very clear and fully justify the fact that the European Commission should have already taken action a long time ago to clarify the functioning of the entry price system, at least with regard to the tomato sector.

However, the Commission has not only not intervened to solve possible pitfalls that could be revealed by the regulation of entry prices in force, but has also negotiated a new agricultural agreement with Morocco without having previously resolved the failures of the current import regime.

Honorable members, it is high time for the European Commission to take its responsibilities seriously and start investigating where frauds occur, and eventually ask for the recovery of unpaid customs duties.
I think that in no way should a new agreement with Morocco be ratified without the details we have presented being resolved.

Our goal is not to slow down the signing of international agreements, but to ensure that these agreements do not seriously harm the interests of European productions and that the rules signed in those agreements are respected.

As for the new agreement with Morocco, the European fruit and vegetable sector only asks for guarantees that the effective compliance with the agreed measures will be carried out, and this is only possible through the reform of the entry-level price regime.
Until we have a new system of entry prices, we cannot have a new agreement with Morocco.
We will not be able to ratify the agreement that the Commission has already closed.

Moreover, if this control is the responsibility of the member states, a significant economic effort should be required from the member states, but it is also true that we have long been demanding that there be a European border and customs system, following the example of the United States, to ensure effective control.

Mr. President, Commissioner, discussing this report in Parliament has been complex, mainly because it has involved these measures that require the approval of the World Trade Organization, and the preliminary proposal of the Commission sent to Parliament is different from the one sent in Geneva.
We believe that it is necessary to help Pakistan, we understand that exceptionally trade preferences can be granted, provided that the sensitivities of the population are taken into account.
European industry, and especially the textile sector, which in communities such as the Valencian Community in Spain suffers severely from the consequences of the crisis.

But this report has allowed us to verify that the measures that can be taken within the framework of international trade cannot be dealt with with the urgency that these acts need, so we should learn for the future.

Helping Pakistan, yes, but not with the Commission's original proposal, as it does not take into account the effects of the European industry in terms of the deadlines for the application of sensitive products.
It would even delay the implementation of these measures because they do not coincide with the pending text to be approved by the WTO. We would be out of time.
Therefore, we consider it unacceptable to maintain this proposal and we think we will have to vote against it.
Mr. President, I would like to start my speech by congratulating all those who have made it possible to reach an agreement.
It is an agreement that we should all be pleased about, because it affects the daily lives of all citizens, but with the constructive spirit that characterizes me, I would like to make some points.
First of all, I would like to draw attention to the importance of providing accurate, relevant, but above all understandable and uniform information.
For consumers, exhaustive information about the components of textile products will be of no use if citizens are not able to decipher it later.
We have taken a necessary but not sufficient positive step. We should move forward and protect citizens who could become more vulnerable.
Honorable members, it is essential to establish a European system for labeling sizes based on body sizes, because the first thing we find when we are going to buy a garment is the size.
That is why we should be much more ambitious and seek harmonization of sizes.
Mr. President, three notes on the situation created around cucumbers.
I am the grandson of a German and I have a great affection for that country, but it is clear that the German authorities have acted in this case with haste and recklessness.

On the other hand, if we analyze the European action, we notice that the one developed by the Food Safety Authority and the Commission has been vague, very blurred and imprecise, it has not been able to coordinate or direct.
Third, the victims are entitled to economic compensation quickly.
But for the moment I propose to this Parliament that we organize in Brussels or here in Strasbourg a great exhibition of European gastronomy based precisely on cucumber.
We must reclaim the lost honor, an expression that is grateful to the German writer Heinrich Bell: we must reclaim the lost honor of cucumber producers.
Europe is the right scenario for this.
Mr. President, first of all, I am forced to express my sincere condolences for the twenty-three victims who have already died, twenty-two in Germany and one in Sweden.
And this crisis must be said to be the most conclusive proof that the European Union must improve its food alert system and its internal coordination a lot.
The involved member states have shown slowness, inefficiency, inoperability, and at this point, after twenty-three deaths, we still do not know where the problem comes from.

The European Commission must seriously reflect on the problems it causes through its irresponsible actions or inaction in times of crisis like the current one, causing cases of economic ruin, of destruction of jobs that were previously insecure.

stable, unemployment, defenselessness and, of course, a health crisis with very high health risks for the population. Because while you, from the Commission, echoed irresponsible statements from regional authorities

German women were very misinformed and quite irresponsible, with names and surnames of Spanish farms, while the population continued to be exposed, without knowing it, to the bacterium, believing they were avoiding it, citizens were more exposed than ever to eating something that could harm them.

The European Commission should, today, at the Agriculture Council, which is held in Luxembourg at two o'clock in the afternoon, propose to the ministers that part of the two and a half million euros that exist be used as unused remains of the common agricultural policy.
those two and a half billion euros to repair the damage as much as possible.
To do this, it is necessary to find a legal loophole that allows it, a legal loophole that has already been found on other occasions, such as mad cows or dioxins, and that should be found now.
Therefore, Commissioners, Ministers, today in Luxembourg you must live up to your responsibility.

German authorities, in addition, given the irresponsible accusations made, should undoubtedly support this economic solution from the beginning and also support, with their own funds, communication campaigns to restore the lost consumer confidence in fruit and vegetable productions.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, nothing we do here or in the European Union will bring the dead back to life, and hopefully what is being done will prevent more and stop the chain of patients who are suffering without having done anything to be there.

We probably don't know the causes, but we do know some things that we have to call by their name. There has been negligence in political actions and there has been negligence in the German federal government. It cannot act as if Hamburg were a city, a state of another continent.

The arrogance that Mrs. Merkel and her Minister of Health have in addressing other states with unusual frequency, if they had translated it into diligence and effectiveness to coordinate, some of the things that have happened would not have happened.

And this negligence has had criminal consequences for a state, which has been the Spanish state, and for its most important sector, agriculture, and has led to the ruin of thousands of people and small business owners, and has discredited the economy for a long time.
I ask you to go to the Council and ask for full compensation for those affected, since we cannot ask for the lives of the dead.
and that the control systems are reviewed.
and that Mrs. Merkel is held accountable.
and that less arrogance and more diligence are asked of him.
and that he is held responsible for the damage he has caused.
He cannot ignore the fact that Hamburg is in his state.
It cannot ignore its responsibilities.
It cannot take refuge under a decentralized and federal state to cause the damage it has caused.

A little more humility, a little more good management and a little less conservatism would have been very good so that this crisis would not get out of hand and Spain and other farmers in the south would not have to suffer its painful consequences.
Review the controls, review the alert systems and demand accountability, because in Spain we are asking you, Commissioner, the Council and the German State.
Mr. President, we are facing a public health problem, an epidemic, as the Commissioner said, and in the face of this, the culprit has been sought, but not the cause.

The system has not worked. We have twenty-two dead, one thousand six hundred affected, and we do not know the cause three weeks later. And by appealing to a precautionary principle without scientific basis, I repeat, without scientific basis, Spain is blamed.
Honourable Members, Spanish cucumbers were not contaminated.
They were not contaminated, I repeat, because some opposing versions have been heard here.
But, so that you can see the importance of what these words have caused, three hundred zero jobs can be affected, a loss of confidence.
An epidemic knows no borders.

I agree with you, Commissioner, it knows no borders. We ask for responsibility for what has not been done, for what we must do immediately, because Germany has a risk problem at this moment, it has the largest number of affected, but Spain is not to blame.
We are asking for compensation.
What is important and what unites us here today are the victims, because no one should feel as unprotected as European consumers do today.
And it is out of respect for the victims that we need clarity and responsibility.

And it is my responsibility to denounce the German authorities who unfairly and hastily accused Spanish cucumbers, and specifically the cooperatives of Malaga and Almería, which were models of exploitation and will not recover from those accusations.
Thousands of families without work are wondering why, why they need an answer and, above all, what their future will be, not only in Andalusia, but in all of Europe.

Therefore, and trusting that experts will find a solution quickly, I demand that the Commission, when it goes to speak with the Council today, asks for immediate economic and moral measures for all producers who from Andalusia and from all over Europe look to us with indignation but with hope.
Instead of prioritizing European research and collaboration, the German authorities have slandered and harmed cucumber producers and others.
And no one in Germany has resigned yet, nor has anyone offered reparations that would be commensurate with the damage caused.
It is Germany that has a serious credibility problem.
Mrs. Merkel's treatment of the countries of the South in terms of agriculture and also finances is intolerable.
Someone said that Merkel was a disciple of Adenauer and Kohl.
None of that, it lacks credit, morale.
Mr. President, it is no coincidence that Spain, Italy, Greece, Ireland, Portugal and some other countries agree on our reluctance to accept the so-called Eurovignette.

The coincidence, the criticism, is the cause of our peripheral countries, which, in the end, will be the ones who pay this singular tax that will be collected by the European Union states that have geographical centrality.
The ratio that inspires the Eurovignette incurs great contradictions and the discourse of support is becoming weaker every day.

Although the rationality of internalizing external costs is accepted as a starting point, in the end, it is not sustained that, to alleviate congestion, only high-tonnage vehicles are penalized, leaving out tourism, in the same terms that the old slogan of the polluter pays is applied with evident discrimination.

On the other hand, ladies and gentlemen, the Eurovignette, which was conceived as a source of infrastructure funding, will ultimately only be 15% allocated to the financing of trans-European networks, and not in a mandatory manner.

But as a simple recommendation, so that the Minister of Finance in office will allocate the collected funds to the purpose he considers most convenient for the interests of his country within the broad chapter of infrastructure.
The final result will be nothing more than a stick to the transportation of goods by road, which is currently the only mode that the internal market is allowing.
This is the reality, ladies and gentlemen, a reality that is much more crude in a context of economic crisis.

In this sense, the competitiveness of European products in the world markets cannot be allowed to experiment that can contribute to further deteriorating the precarious situation of the European economy with the imposition of new additional costs.

The food crisis, which has recklessly fallen on Spanish products, has produced an unfair penalty and huge losses for those who are penalized by the Eurovignette, freight carriers and primary crop farmers.
These are the reasons, ladies and gentlemen, why the Spanish delegation of the European People's Party will vote against this draft directive.

You will all understand, dear colleagues, that when I take over the presidency of the session, I express my pain and my consternation over the death of Jorge Semprun, which occurred a few hours ago at the age of eighty-seven.

In Jorges Emprun we celebrated the prisoner of the Buchenwald concentration and extermination camp, the fighter against the forces of Nazism in France and against the Franco dictatorship in my country, Spain.
We also celebrate the remarkable committed writer, particularly a collaborator of our program The European Book of the Year, and we also celebrate the convinced Europeanist politician.

I mourn his death as well as his companion and friend, and I am going to ask President Buzek to address his family members and the Spanish government a message of condolences and solidarity that I am sure we all share here.
creation of an economic governance space governed by the principles of federalism adapted to European construction.
We can't keep turning a blind eye.
It is inconsistent to have a single currency and at the same time lack the fiscal and financial instruments that this currency requires.
Specifically, therefore, we need the issuance of European debt, a clear no to competition between the debt issuances of the States, the creation of a genuine European public treasury,
Harmonization of tax policies that guarantee the equality of citizens, combat tax fraud and help define a progressive European social policy based on effective public services.
These ideas are, I will be told, elementary.
But they have to be repeated and repeated because nobody listens to them.
And precisely because they do not listen, those dark times are running that the poet Bertolt Brecht spoke of.

Mr. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the current economic and financial crisis we are experiencing highlights the need for regional policy as the best instrument to reduce the differences in development between regions and states.
At the same time, we can recover the positive image of Europe that citizens have lately only associated with tough adjustment plans and social cuts.

The future cohesion policy, the pillar of solidarity, the European project and social justice, must take into account the following priorities: first, to strengthen social cohesion and to integrate the challenges posed by the 2020 Strategy. Second, to take into account the needs and characteristics of the European Union.

Third, maintain the principle of graduality in the perception of funds, so that regions do not abandon the convergence objective, avoiding sudden changes in the perception of aid, and fourth, promote a system
equitable.
Finally, ladies and gentlemen, the authorities are applying tough budgetary adjustment policies.
Therefore, the support of the Union is necessary.
I hope the Council will take good note.

In defense of fundamental rights, I ask the responsible institutions to review the designation of San Sebastian as the European Capital of Culture, because I believe it was chosen following a political criterion, which is discrimination against other aspiring cities.

The president of the court said that she was chosen to support the peace process. And as far as I know, in Spain there is a terrorist organization called ETA, which to this day has not abandoned its arms and which two months ago managed to get its political arm Bildu to govern, among other municipalities, San Sebastián.
I don't think we in Europe should give such a strong voice to those who do not condemn terrorist violence and who will do propaganda to share the blame among victims and murderers.
murderers? Where is the right to freedom and dignity?
Of course not in San Sebastián, where our colleagues, like Mayor Oreja, Iturgaiz, Salva or myself, must be escorted.
I believe in the culture of life, not in the culture of shooting.
Honorable members, can there be true culture without freedom?
No, and a thousand times no.
And when San Sebastian is a city free for all, let it re-present its candidacy, and while they learn the culture of respect for those who think differently.
Because tomorrow they may deserve it, but today, with Batasuna and his heirs in the institutions, they do not deserve it.
Mr. President, first of all, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for the fruitful collaboration they have provided me with in drafting it.
And I say the same about the other fellow members of the committee of this Parliament.
Sixty years ago, the European Coal and Steel Community was created. There is nothing better to commemorate this event than to debate now about energy infrastructure in Europe.

Today, the European Union has clearly set the objectives of its common European internal market policy, promoting renewable energy as a means or instrument of the fight against climate change, security of supply and diversification of its sources.
The Treaty of Lisbon has consecrated a title to energy, the twenty-first, where these commitments I have just mentioned appear, and also the promotion of the interconnection of energy networks.
Well, the objective of the report we have drawn up is to correct energy infrastructures that, in the opinion of the European Commission, are outdated and poorly interconnected.
For example, we are seeing a spectacular increase in wind-based electricity generation in the North Sea and the Baltic, with the immense potential for renewable energy in the south of the country.
Europe and North Africa, with the problems that arise from large-scale electricity storage, with the need to recharge electric vehicles, among many other urgent issues.
It is impossible to face all of this today if we do not devise new networks and new connections, both within the European Union and with third countries.

Therefore, in the coming years, it is a matter of making progress in determining the necessary infrastructures, establishing the criteria that will allow the selection of projects of European interest.
b, eliminating energy islands c, guaranteeing the execution of these projects within reasonable timeframes and arbitrating formulas to solve the conflictive issue of
authorization and licensing procedures in the member states, ensuring funding that attracts and promotes private investment without prejudice to the necessary public support.
Energy efficiency and savings, as well as smart grids, are central ingredients in the new design incorporated into the report because we have
I believe that by reducing energy demand, we can reduce our dependence on imports, with the consequent effect on infrastructure needs.
The main concern of this report from the very beginning has been the processing of the licenses and authorizations aimed at allowing the execution of the necessary works.
Currently, they are eternal.
And they drag on due to the population's opposition to seeing towers or other facilities grow in their neighborhood.

To resolve this conflict, the early information of the citizens has been considered and a warning system has been established in the event that the authorities of a State do not respond to a request within a reasonable timeframe.
We are facing ambitious goals for which everyone's contribution is necessary.
In this sense, companies in the sector are essential, and they are calling for a stable regulatory framework, the best way to ensure the financing of their efforts.
So far, the European Union's energy policy, both towards the external borders and within them, has lacked a decisively European impetus.
Europe must speak with one voice, a voice that is well audible and resonates fully in the vault of the European building, because it is from our energy fragility that we must.
To gather the strength to build an energetically solid and vigorous Europe, worthy of the successor in this anniversary year of that great invention that was the ECSC, our cradle, precisely.

There is still a lot to be done.
We will have to improve the safety nets and make them more agile and effective.
We must bet on further developing the sector in the value chain, controlling that there is no distribution of quotas, especially in certain areas, or promoting quality policy.

But without a doubt, with our positive vote and with everything that remains to be done, today many farmers will be able to see this Parliament defending their labor right, the most basic of all, which is to be able to live with dignity from the income of their work.
B. has rightly pointed out the disastrous consequences that the approval of this agreement would entail.
Because this agreement, which extends quotas for certain fruit and vegetable products when the figures of the present agreement are not respected, makes absolutely no sense.

It is worth remembering that the Spanish Federation of Fruit and Vegetable Exporters denounced the massive entry of tomatoes through Perpignan at a price lower than the one indicated in the Agreement before the Committee on Petitions, precisely of this Parliament.
Illegal situations like the one described put the European farmer at a competitive disadvantage.
It should also be added that our farmers must respect strict environmental and social quality standards that our Moroccan partners do not always respect.
Finally, I would like to highlight the issue of the Sahara.
According to the United Nations Charter, the Sahara is an autonomous territory and the exploitation of its resources must have an impact precisely on the local population.
Moreover, it constitutes an area over which the United Nations does not recognize the sovereignty of the Kingdom of Morocco.
The European Union must ensure compliance with international law.

I am in favor of an agreement with Morocco, in favor of an agreement that establishes strict control mechanisms from the European Union in relation to quotas and prices, an agreement that fights against dumping, that does not exploit the Moroccan farmer and, above all, that dignifies our European farmers.
This is certainly not the case with this agreement.

Last year, the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions asked the European Commission to proceed with a modification of the price entry regime for fruits and vegetables in the Union, a regime that is facilitating the fraudulent entry of products from third countries, as stated by the Union's own anti-fraud agency, OLAF.
They are mainly Moroccan tomatoes.
The same request was included in a statement signed last year by the governments of Spain, France and Italy.

This fraud is fixed by modifying the regulation on the application of the common organization of the market for agricultural products, because the alignment of the Customs Code does not solve the problem, Commissioner.

For several years, I have defended within the Popular Party the need to stop new concessions to Morocco until the European Union provides itself with the necessary instruments that guarantee compliance with the current agreement.
The European Commission argues that it is the Member States that must guarantee the control of imports.

However, what the Commission does not say is that the entry price regime is in force and that it prevents national customs authorities from making a correct traceability of the prices declared by importers to verify that there are no irregularities.

Make changes to the regulation for the application of the CMO for agricultural products and we will have solved part of the problem, because if not, the legal loophole in European regulations prevents national authorities from doing their job correctly.
Unwritten. Again, dear colleagues, the debate on a summit.
Many have been celebrated, all announced with great fame, trying to create an expectation that is getting smaller every day.
They are no longer credible because they do not contribute to solving the crisis.
Summits in which the same agreements are repeated again and again.

It should be known that as long as there is no progress in the political union and in strengthening this Parliament and the Executive Power of the European Commission, the summits will be repeated, but the economic crisis will be aggravated.
In a nutshell, two ideas: the first is the need to insist that responsible solidarity and the fulfillment of duties are the
The second is that the use of structural funds that have not been disbursed should be authorized immediately.
These amounts can easily allow us to combat the unemployment figures of young European citizens.

Madam President, from the European Parliament, I would like to pay tribute today to all women, who, despite the fact that we have made a lot of progress since March 1911, when women took to the streets to demand votes and better working conditions, I believe that women's equality is still far away.
Today, women can work without having to ask anyone for permission, but in many cases they still earn less than men for a similar job, which is unacceptable.
We must also remember the women in rural areas whose work is ignored.
I believe that another uncomfortable reality, but one that must continue to be denounced, is violence against women.

This year alone, there have been an excessive number of women murdered, not counting the serious threats from those who believe they have the right to exercise physical or psychological violence against them.
It is time to say enough and to say it loud and clear.
From this Parliament, I reiterate my commitment to the European Protection Order for Victims and the Victims Directive presented by the Commission, which will be voted on, God willing, next June.
We also have to say and I would like to remind you that motherhood remains an obstacle to the progression of women and I believe that this is a trend that should be changed.
I want to send a message of hope and, with the help of more and more men, many women, we must move forward on the path of equal opportunities, rights and also duties.
We have come a long way, but there is still a lot to be done.
I have to admit that I don't believe in quotas at all and deeply, but I have to tell you that something has to be done and I agree with that.
Many of my colleagues and, of course, with Mrs. Reding, to open this debate and to move forward on this path so that women regain the place they deserve, and with that, you can count on my help.

Mr. President, in a situation of economic crisis and budget cuts that are affecting public health so much, and in which, as in the case of the community in which I live, research centers such as Prince Philippe, specialized in diabetes, are left without funds, this Resolution comes better than ever, it is absolutely appropriate.

We need a common European strategy against diabetes and we need a Council recommendation that tells the States that they have to increase research, even with stem cells, that they have to coordinate their results to optimize them, that they have to establish healthy eating and lifestyle habits programs.

In summary, we have to put people's health above other things, and in this case, research, coordination and making national programs coordinated by the Commission and asking for results on diabetes is to guarantee the quality of life of Europeans and to guarantee their own lives.

If we spend more money on this, some will take a bit longer to collect, but I am sure that those who are having problems now will have a better quality of life and we will be fulfilling one of our obligations as States, as the Council and as the Commission, which is to take care of the health of our citizens.
Mr. President, of the many issues that this debate raises, I would like to highlight the issue of the emission rights market, a market that was born with defects, certainly.
But today the limitation of rights and the economic crisis have meant a drastic reduction in the price of carbon, that is, this price is so low that it is cheap to pollute.
It is therefore urgent to reform the design of a policy on this market, because its deterioration threatens all green efforts, the entire green policy of the European Union.
If emission rights are not valued, the increase in emissions is being incentivized. Polluting industries will not invest in new techniques, and what is worse,
The financing of important projects, such as energy efficiency projects or carbon storage plants, will be put at risk.
This is the risk.
It is up to us, the Commission and the Parliament, to conjure it.
Mr. President, there are few asylum seekers permanently resettled in Europe.
My country, Spain, has just started with the experience.
However, the cases are of urgent necessity.
The deputies have verified this on the ground, on a trip to the Iraqi camps of Palestinian origin in Syria, as well as the news that came to us from Tunisia.
Another more institutional aspect is the balance of power between the Parliament and the Council.
Our speaker, the brave Rui Tavares. There are many good parliamentarians, but few with as much tenacity as Rui Tavares.
Tavares has fought for the European Parliament to maintain the new competences gained after the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon.
I cannot forget the permanent work that UNHCR has carried out, without which success would not have been possible either.
UNHCR has made us all aware of the urgency of the report so that the funds can be used as soon as possible, now that they are so much needed.
And, finally, thank you very much, Commissioner, and I hope that we will also give you and your good heart the satisfaction of pushing forward the asylum package next month.

The European social model we so much boast of is not only based on our pension, education or health systems, but also on a way of understanding the balances between employer and worker within companies.

The labor reform approved by the Spanish government without dialogue and without consensus breaks with that social model and takes us away from the objectives of the 2020 Strategy, both in terms of job creation and its quality.
A labor reform alone does not create jobs, it does economic growth.
What a labor law does is define the conditions under which workers enter companies, the conditions under which they remain in them, and the conditions under which they leave them.
And with this reform, where eighty percent of workers will be unprotected because they will not be subject to collective agreements, where they can be fired due to a decrease in companies'income.

They will be able to unilaterally modify their schedules, but what is clear is that workers will enter with greater precariousness, remain in the labor market with more fear and leave it with less compensation.

Therefore, this reform, which attacks the European social model and which is committed to the competitiveness of the Spanish economy only in relation to the conditions of workers, deserves a general strike, like the one that must be called tomorrow in Spain in defense of this social model.

Mr. President, Mr. Barroso, let me say right away that the Spanish delegation of the European People's Party finds it correct and endorses the two packages you have presented today, both the labor package and the solidarity aid to Greece, which has a lot to do with the coherence of your approach.
It is undeniable, ladies and gentlemen, that we are living through difficult times and that the events of each day remind us that the crisis is still far from being resolved.
The focus of attention has inevitably been put on Spain again.
The markets have been unjustifiably sounded, partly encouraged by statements that, in my opinion, Mr. President, are inopportune.
Some in the context of important elections, in which both contenders cited my country as a dialectical element of confrontation.
Of course, we do not appreciate any of the references.
On the other hand, no one, to divert attention from their own problems, also deals with us with little political delicacy.
Today, some of them have not been so delicate here, as the Italians would say, and there has been some lack of political delicacy.
Honorable members, the situation of the markets does not reflect the strength of Spain.
We are a solvent country with the full capacity to face its debts.
Spanish debt remains lower than the European Union average, and the Spanish government is fully committed to meeting the deficit targets agreed with the European Union.
Mr. Svoboda, Mr. Rajoy has never said that he cannot meet the objectives set by the European Union.
He said the opposite, that he is willing to fulfill each and every one of those objectives, and reiterates it every day.

The Spanish government, in the few months it has been at the head of the Executive, has adopted and will continue to adopt very ambitious measures to guarantee fiscal consolidation and lay the foundations for an improvement in competitiveness, job creation and growth.
The IMF's forecasts, by the way, yesterday confess to the IMF itself that they are prior to the analysis of the decisions and measures taken by the Spanish Government at present.
Other measures we have adopted are the general state budgets for 2012, which in our opinion will guarantee that this year the deficit target is met, and the organic budget stability law.

It will present a reform of education and health care, which will involve an adjustment of one billion euros. The reform of the financial sector will also undoubtedly contribute to the fact that financial institutions will have to provide more than fifty billion euros.
In summary, Spain is meeting the objectives set by the Union and the Commission, and what we are asking for is responsibility from everyone.

It is necessary that we all save ourselves together, and Spain with all of us, without a doubt, and criticism of one or the other does not contribute anything, or we are all countries capable of being together and contributing to growth and the new path, or, if not, it will be difficult, of course, to move forward in the terms proposed by the Commission.
Mr. Romeva, do you want to make Mr. Rajoy, the President of the Government, the protagonist?
I think it's fine, I wouldn't have any problems.
But Mr. Rajoy is not the protagonist of the crisis.

The protagonist of the crisis is the legacy received by the Spanish socialist, communist and green left, which has left the worst legacy that any government has ever left, when they received the best legacy that any government ever had.
Mr. President, this morning I read in an important German newspaper the news that Spain and Argentina have a conflict related to an oil company.
This is just the wrong way to approach the matter.
The conflict is between Europe and Argentina, and beyond, with that great European value, which is legal security and its respect in international trade relations.
European institutions have magnificent jurists who can find the appropriate instruments in the original or derived Community law to neutralize the arbitrariness of the Argentine authorities.
I am a modest professor of public law and I offer to collaborate with them.
The credibility of the European Union in the eyes of the citizens is currently at stake.

Mr. President, from the Committee on Agriculture, we share the ultimate goal of this directive, to try to guide the composition of our energy mixes from taxation, but we are facing a very complex debate.

Full of edges in economic, social and environmental terms, it is important to maintain those balances that will make us move forward more in environmental terms, yes, but that will not harm us in economic terms and that will not create greater social crises than the ones we are already experiencing.
This is the case with agriculture.

As everyone knows, energy costs are increasingly a very important part of the fixed costs of our agricultural holdings, at a time when we are also in a debate in which the crises of the raw materials markets are combined with a perspective of losing aid and increasing health and environmental requirements that are marginal to their profitability.
That is why we have asked for two things in principle.

The first is the maintenance of zero-type deductions in the energy component, now linked to the drafting and implementation of energy efficiency and savings strategies in rural areas, and the incorporation of the
agriculture within the sectors considered at risk of carbon leakage, so that they can also access the allowed deductions in the CO2 emissions section.
That is, a more environmentally demanding policy, but one that maintains those balances that make our rural environment viable at a time of changes and uncertainties in it.
We are experiencing a great controversy that has the concepts of austerity and growth as essential references.
If you hear the noise that is being formed, it would seem that the idea of growth is a bright invention of these days.
nothing further from reality.
In Europe, the pact called Stability and Growth has been in place since 1997.

That is why a large part of the policies carried out by European institutions, such as those of regional cohesion and research, are policies aimed at growth and that pursue the development and well-being of citizens.

Therefore, I address the Commission and the members of this Parliament who have more chances of being heard: no complex on our part when it comes to being in that debate that we can face with our heads held high.
This is, in my opinion, the minority among those who are not registered.
Madam President, first of all, let me thank all my colleagues and, above all, the shadow rapporteurs for their help in this report, which has made this report much stronger.

We all know that the twentieth anniversary of the implementation of the single market is coming to an end, which should be the engine of economic activity and growth in Europe, the key to getting out of the crisis and achieving the objectives of Europe 2020.
In these twenty years, the construction of the internal market must be made compatible with its development, with a broad framework of consumer protection, growth and rights that generate dynamism.
and trust, transparency, the basic principle of democracy and good governance, to which Commissioner Barnier referred this afternoon, and cooperation between the Commission and Parliament.
It is time now to develop the regulatory framework for the protection and training of consumers, and particularly vulnerable consumers.
We know that the diversity of vulnerability situations, both endogenous and exogenous, makes it difficult to adopt a global legislative instrument.
This forces us to address the problem of vulnerability from a transversal analysis that takes into account the different needs, capabilities and circumstances of consumers.
The Commission, being aware of the current shortcomings, has focused its strategy on improving consumer information and education.
Although it is an ambitious proposal, it is not enough to protect vulnerable consumers, because their vulnerability is born precisely from their lack of assertiveness and understanding of the
information they receive or the available options or their lack of knowledge of the existing claim and compensation systems, especially in the case of cross-border and online consumption.

It is for all these reasons that, in order to solve the shortcomings, that is, the problems, it is necessary to adopt a strategy to reinforce vulnerable consumers and that both the Commission and the Member States introduce specific measures in their legislation to guarantee adequate protection.

that goes beyond mere information, especially in those areas where the level has been proven to be higher and where the highest number of consumer complaints are recorded, the financial sector, whose complexity implies that, in essence, any consumer can become vulnerable.

Therefore, the financial services industry is asked to redouble its efforts to provide understandable, truthful information, providing clear explanations and using direct language about the nature of the products and services it offers. The food sector, in relation to advertising,

from foods with a high fat, salt and sugar content, and to children and young people who are most sensitive to the advertising of these foods, the transportation sector, which often continues to have difficulties when vulnerable people travel, the energy and telecommunications sector

where the lack of transparency in some cases causes additional difficulties for consumers, for example, in the energy sector when determining the rate that best suits their needs, in access to justice, where consumers may find it difficult to access the mechanisms.
Therefore, the Commission and the Member States are asked, and allow me to draw the attention of the Spanish Minister of Justice, Mr. Gallardón, so that rights are not retreated.
and go in the opposite direction of the march of these difficult times, putting intelligence and good governance in favor of an alternative resolution of consumer disputes.
Finally, I would like to say that any of us is likely to become vulnerable consumers. Thank you very much and thank you to all the deputies for their help in strengthening this report.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I have a feeling of despair, almost frustration, that I must share with someone.
It will allow me to do it this afternoon with you.

This is the third or fourth debate we have had in this House lately on the situation of youth unemployment throughout Europe, and debate after debate, while youth unemployment rates are skyrocketing in some Member States, we are already close to

fifty percent of the active population, while many of them are already left without any kind of social coverage or unemployment, while all this is happening, while we are moving from a situation that evolves from worrying to.

Sustainable and from unsustainable to dramatic. The Commission presents itself once again in this Parliament, in this Chamber, as if it were a political commentator, as if it were just another analyst, and not as the true Government of the Union, which is what it is and, moreover, what we need.

Mr. Commissioner, governing is setting priorities, governing is setting priorities, taking the initiative, and also with the aim of achieving some goal, and, in addition, the Commission is not doing so.
Governing is not just about restructuring funds, nor even announcing it to wash one's face in public opinion, but about developing an ambitious, lasting and quick strategy to end youth unemployment.

Governing is not resigning to a youth unemployment rate above twenty percent and being satisfied with a pilot project of four million euros, which is ridiculous given the situation and the magnitude of the problem we are facing.

Governing is not giving in to the pressures of the College of Commissioners or other Council member states that are trying to convince us that we will only emerge from this financial crisis, this new wave of recession, by giving up wages, labor rights or compensation, and that we can only have a future of precariousness as a generation.

Because if this were true, Commissioner, that only with precariousness do we gain competitiveness and that only by being more precarious will we be more competitive, then Zimbabwe would be the most competitive country and it is not.
These are Sweden, Finland and Denmark, which are precisely characterized by a model of relationships and a model of labor guarantees rights.
Mr. President, employment is much more than a citizenship right, it is an instrument of linking with the system, it is an instrument of social integration.
And, therefore, the more unemployment, the greater political disaffection. And, Commissioner, it is no use to me that you talk about competition issues and do nothing about youth unemployment.

Because, Commissioner, when you had to interpret the Treaties in a lax manner to create, for example, the Financial Stability Fund, you did it, and when the Treaties had to be reformed to comply with or satisfy the delusions of some Member State on austerity issues, we did it too.
So, what do I want to tell you?
For example, there is the youth employment guarantee, it doesn't need to be explained.

Fight for an increase in the budget, use the European Social Fund as an instrument if necessary, design a co-financed and solidarity-based implementation mechanism that will help those who are most unemployed, put pressure to change this social suffocation policy even more in the countries that are going through it the worst, and remember that behind every figure there is a person who is going through it badly.
So, you will think like me that the least is not whose competition, because for all citizens, especially.
Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the INTA Committee for the work done, and the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs.

In general, we are faced with a good regulation of the GSP, which is necessary, and in particular, in some actions, the control of the import rules of textile products that could harm the production of the European Union.
But we are concerned about the exclusion, starting from 2014, of certain countries that are classified as middle-high income countries, such as Latin America, from the GSP.
Because what about these middle-income countries that have little diversified exports?
Why not introduce a diversification criterion for exports?

Because in this, two speeds could be produced: countries like Costa Rica, Cuba, and Ecuador would benefit from it, differentiating themselves from potentially developed countries like China and Brazil.

Therefore, I believe we must support a transition period and that amendments will be presented with this transition period to adapt to this situation in these countries and give them the possibility to open negotiations and trade agreements with them so that they can benefit from it.

Mr. President, I supported Mrs. Nadelcheva's report when I was able to accompany her on the Congo mission, along with other parliamentarians, and I have indeed seen few peoples with a greater willingness to make democracy and participate in it.
But a people, in order to believe in democracy, also needs to believe in its state and its government, and that will not be possible only with electoral support or external support.
They also need to demand a fight against corruption and break the indecent paradox that means living in misery in one of the world's richest countries in resources.

And it must be said and denounced that some of the violence they experience is imported or at least encouraged by those unscrupulous multinationals that, from Europe or other continents or other states, are capable of participating in corruption without caring to encourage the struggle for those resources to gain the favor of those who lead some territories.

That is why, Mrs. Aston, although it is not your absolute competence, I do say that a greater demand for traceability and transparency for European and other multinationals from other continents that collaborate there would be as useful for the development of that people as the help we can provide at the electoral and technical level.
Mr. President, to the rapporteurs for the valuable work they have presented.
Colleagues, we are now debating package two, after having approved package six, after almost all heads of state and government agreed on two international treaties outside the order.
Community, after many other European rules have created more community authorities for banking supervision, stock market supervision, insurance supervision, and for the risks of the economic system.
a deployment of texts and more texts, reports, proposals that address new economic evaluation criteria, new procedures, new procedures.
We must not stop and apply what we have already approved.
Faced with the instability that the European continent is experiencing, the opposite is needed: stability and legal security.
We don't need a pile of successive legal findings.
I don't know, dear colleagues, if I'm dreaming.
The situation that the rescue entails is very worrying.
The whole truth is not told to Spanish citizens with the new debt that, by endorsing private debt, the Spanish government and state assume as public debt.
The Spanish government has requested aid that it previously said it did not want, and it presents it ridiculously as a triumph, as some colleague has already warned in this debate.
There is no triumph but failure with Bankia and others.

I insist, there is no more correct policy for Europe than the one sponsored by the French government, behind which parliamentary lines must be closed, because we will not get out of the debt without harmonious growth of all and of the whole.

Supervision, as requested in both reports, of course, all the supervision that is necessary, but also essential, simultaneous, anti-speculative growth, as also mentioned in some of the measures of both reports and other reports.
Please, clarity and transparency as well, balance as my colleague Sánchez Presedo said before.
Madam President, since I entered this Parliament, I have not stopped denouncing female genital mutilation.
That silent and accepted crime that millions of women and girls in the world suffer, seventy million, I repeat, seventy million.

An unbearable figure for anyone who stops to study the terrible consequences of these practices, which are hidden under the guise of psychological, health, and religious reasons, all of which are false.

The truth is that ablation, practiced preferably on girls aged fourteen and even one year, can lead to death from hemorrhagic collapse and, in the best case, cause and bring strong psychological consequences due to trauma.
From Europe we must fight with all our strength to eradicate this violation of human rights, which violates the right to equal opportunities, and endangers health.
Ladies and gentlemen, this is about mistreatment, cruelty, and torture against girls, and this degrading treatment also exists in Europe.
To do this, we must activate all the prevention mechanisms available to our legal system, and I encourage our judges to act to prevent genital mutilation.
of girls in Europe, punishing those who carry it out, that the law in Europe speaks with one voice when it comes to combating mutilation on our soil.
Finally, I ask civil society and NGOs to actively engage in education and prevention campaigns.
There is still a long way to go, but we are many who are not going to stop because we owe it to seventy million mutilated women.
Mr. President, Commissioner, I am fully aware that one of the reasons we approved the milk package was precisely to adapt the sector to a market without milk quotas in 2015.

But it is also true that every time this date of liberalization approaches, uncertainty in the sector increases because there is no clear exit strategy, and the reasons why the sector demands prudence and reflection from us in the face of the decision we have are also increasing.

For example, reasons such as the belief in maintaining vineyard planting rights or maintaining sugar quotas at least until 2020, reasons such as the uncertainty that exists in the sector about the real effects of the dairy package and whether

We will have had time to make a serious evaluation of them, and reasons such as uncertainty about where the common agricultural policy is going and especially its budget, that is, about the part of the income that does not come from the markets and that affects our producers.

Therefore, what do we ask you, Commissioner, to convey to Mr. Cholos? That we do not make a policy of dismantling our protection system without a serious and rigorous analysis, because the effects on our producers are irreversible.

Postpone the end of the quota until 2015, until a date that gives security to the sector and opens an open and transparent debate on the regulatory mechanisms, because the markets are even more unfair and the producers are increasingly defenseless.
Mr. President, many members of this Parliament have heard the voice of the citizens, the voice of the street.
Mr. Commissioner, you said that this is a yes or no agreement.
Members of this Parliament also have a responsibility for yes or no.
And we say no because this agreement creates confusion, as is obvious.
The intellectual property rights or the rights of internet users are not clarified.
Internet users, are we concerned about intellectual property rights?
Yes.
