No, it is not a solution, because there are two issues to address, it is not a legal issue, but two political issues: one, determination of the fight against counterfeiting and piracy.
Another is piracy, and another is a new legislative framework for the digital environment, which we have repeatedly asked for from the Socialist Group, and we are asking for it again.
It is their opportunity.
Don't turn your back on society, because tomorrow it will find itself with no and will have no way out.
Improve, that time it is necessary to accentuate the chaos.
The feeling of powerlessness was of such a dimension that Europe had to react by force, and it has done so for the good of all, because the great winner of this last summit was the euro.
And with this triumph, hope has returned that Europe will emerge from its paralysis, moving from reflection to action.
Ladies and gentlemen, at this summit, it was just as necessary to adopt short-term measures to guarantee financial stability as long-term measures to solve the Union's shortcomings.
In this case, the immediate was essential to continue working in favor of the important.
It was imperative to send a message that the euro is a common, irrevocable and irreversible project.

We welcome, ladies and gentlemen, the very important decisions such as empowering the European Stability Mechanism to recapitalize banks directly, which will allow breaking the vicious circle between bank debt and sovereign debt, a thesis always defended, by the way, by the current Spanish Government.
In addition, it will serve to intervene in the markets in support of the public debt of countries that fulfill their commitments to public deficit and reforms.
These were necessary decisions to guarantee financial stability, which must be the top priority of the European Union in the short term.
This is not the time, ladies and gentlemen, for certain countries to resort to nationalist maxims and put obstacles in the way.
I have already said it, it is time to bet on Europe.
Spain, ladies and gentlemen, is adopting and implementing the most ambitious reform agenda of Spanish democracy in record time, which includes a profound labor reform.
In addition, it is carrying out a financial reform based on total transparency, demonstrating its commitment to fiscal consolidation and compliance with deficit objectives.

We also welcome the decision to launch a process for greater economic integration through four blocks: a banking union, a fiscal union, a common economic policy framework, and strengthening democratic legitimacy.
Mr. President, the Community first and then the European Union has always been not only to overcome crises, but to emerge from them strengthened.
I am glad that we have achieved this once again.
Dear colleagues, all our attention is focused on banks, which we hear time and time again are the blood of the social body.
It is likely that this image is accurate, but let us keep in mind that every body is sustained on a spine and joints.
Well, the backbone and the joints of that social body that we call Europe are precisely its transport networks and its energy infrastructures.
It is essential, as is being said this afternoon here in the hemicycle, to mobilize private funding and, if necessary, public funding.
And, in addition, it is an opportunity to promote the issuance of private debt, backed by European institutions, specifically intended for these purposes, and open to any investor.
Congratulations to the rapporteurs for their work and also to the Commission for their clear promotion of these projects.

Mr. President, dear Commissioner, Minister, in which I greet the new Presidency, I am a veteran militant of the disappeared non-aligned movement that led your country and that strongly desires the territorial integrity of Cyprus in the face of military occupations.

Honorable members, we should have taken advantage of the opportunity for a broader reform of the Court, perhaps, but the Commission's and my fellow rapporteur's claims are very positive and should be supported with the unanimity that our Commission had.
The agility and proper functioning of the Court are basic principles that I doubt with the new, today delayed patent jurisdiction.
Congratulations to the rapporteur. Let's move forward with the reform of the Court.

Mr. President, Commissioner Reding, my country has experienced too many setbacks since the arrival of the Popular Party in government, repeated and continuous attempts to retreat in consolidated rights, such as covering up the little to those who disagree, among others, to consumer organizations.
The threat to Facua, trampling, among others, articles sixteen and seventeen of the Spanish Constitution by Mrs. Mato's Ministry, is a dangerous attack.

Not only freedom of expression and opinion, but also the right to a high level of consumer protection, basic principles of democracy and enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.
I therefore ask for the rectification of Mr. Rajoy's government in the face of the abuse of illegalizing FACUA and I call on the Commission to guarantee the protection of
It must protect the rights of Spanish consumers and act against the reduction of the rights and functions of consumer associations that the current Spanish government intends to impose.
Madam President, Commissioner, first of all, I would like to highlight the great work of Mrs. MacAvan, the rapporteur, and also the other shadow rapporteurs, in reaching this agreement.
The first reading agreement was very important, as the regulation we had approved in 2010 came into effect and it was necessary to revise it.
Not because it was bad legislation, the legislation was very good, but as has been said, the recent events of all known events have shown that there was a certain.
There was a gap that needed to be corrected so that it would not happen again, and specific points of surveillance and safety of medicines once they were marketed had to be reinforced.

Therefore, as has been said, from now on, holders of a marketing authorization for a medicine who do not renew, withdraw or request withdrawal or suspend authorization will have the right to use the medicine.
The obligation to declare the real reasons and motives that led to the withdrawal or suspension of the authorization of a medicine.
This is a great achievement in the name of transparency and will prevent the holder of a marketing authorization from trying to hide the true reasons for his decision.
In addition, in the event that any of these actions are carried out in a third country, all the Member States concerned where this medicine is marketed must be informed.
Everything will improve transparency and safety without overburdening the European Medicines Agency and national agencies.

The second important modification that has been achieved is that all authorized products that are subject to a post-authorization safety study are automatically included in a list of products subject to this monitoring.
Finally, we cannot forget that pharmacovigilance plays a fundamental role and that is why this plenary must approve this proposal.
Mr. President, the agreement reached by the Parliament and the Council reflects what the Member States involved unanimously approved at the IMO.
These seas present a worrying state in terms of acidification.
Moreover, its regeneration capacity is very limited.
The required fuels will be more expensive, and that is why economic aid is expected for entrepreneurs, which is very reasonable.
But some colleagues have tried to apply the requirements for new fuels to all seas of the European Union.

We would find ourselves with the paradox that an environmental problem of some countries of the Union is wanted to be solved by creating a first-order economic problem in the Mediterranean, which does not have that problem, but which has another type of environmental problems whose costs are not intended to be imposed on the rest of the countries.
The Treaty is very clear.
Sensitive areas must be protected
But not all areas are equally sensitive.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to thank once again all those who have made this Directive a reality, the Secretariat, the Commissioner, the rapporteur, all those I have forgotten and all the colleagues who have been with us.
I want to tell the victims, absolutely all of them, without distinction, that for us, they and their families have a face, they have a name, they are real, and precisely in their name.

We will work so that this directive is not just a piece of paper, but that, with the commitment and help of Commissioner Reding, which I absolutely do not doubt, it is implemented quickly and effectively, which is what we all hope for and what everyone expects.
citizen.

I believe that there are different groups of victims who would have wanted and still want their own directive, but I will tell you that the directive we will vote on tomorrow does not forget any victims and therefore does not forget them either.
And I am sure that this is a first and important step, which will be followed by many other steps that will open those doors of justice that have been closed to the victims for too long.
When asked in my country what you do in Europe, I can say with great pride that I am legislating in favor of the victims.
And that work honors me deeply personally and gives me a lot of strength to keep working.

I am sure that with the support and commitment not only of those who work here in Europe, but also in our countries, we will all succeed, and also with the support of the honourable members, in bringing the victims out of this unjust forgetfulness.

Mr. President, Mr. Turmes has done an admirable job because, in order to push through a rule like this, the courage of this rapporteur was needed, who has been able to neutralize the many obstacles and has skillfully arranged them.
It was worth it because efficiency in the use of energy and its savings are requirements of any energy policy worthy of the name.

We should congratulate ourselves on important measures such as the requirement to renovate public buildings, the imposition of a percentage of accumulated energy savings on energy companies, as well as mandatory audits on large private companies.
Now, the work of Turmes and the rest of the rapporteurs will be of no use if it is not accompanied by decisive action from the Member States.
An action that, in turn, must be accompanied by a firm commitment to these objectives from the regions, municipalities and European citizens.
I am interested in highlighting the participation of the latter.
For the moment, what is noticeable is a lot of frivolity among the authorities and among the citizens.
Dear colleagues, do we not see people sitting on street terraces with heating in the harsh European winter?
Friend Turnes, we should not spare efforts to save energy.
The rapporteur, Iracha García, should be congratulated for the work she has done and for the agreement reached between the Parliament and the Council of Ministers.
It is a shame that the Council is not with us tonight.
The new quality scheme for agricultural products simplifies the system and streamlines the existing authorization procedures, and that is good news.

Furthermore, it is a good achievement that the obligation to use the Community logo for designations of origin and protected geographical indications has been included, because this allows for better visibility of European products.
I also think it is noteworthy that the provisions for the protection of quality appeals in bilateral agreements with third countries are strengthened and a legal basis is created.
To defend the European Union logo in those third countries, because I sincerely believe that the protection of European products in third countries must be an indispensable goal.

It is a pity that this package was left a bit blurred during the negotiation, and it is a pity, I say again, that the Council is not here to listen to it, because the original quality package that I proposed

The Commission has somewhat forgotten the commercial standards and the management of supply by quality designations of origin, which are detached from the agreement and, as I say, leaving it somewhat empty.
I believe that we must eliminate the closure that the Council has shown in these two matters, refusing to listen to the positions of the Parliament, which are reasonable.
The management of supply by designations of origin should have been defended and will certainly be defended in the CMO.

Mr. President, the trade agreement with Central America, Colombia and Peru is an important agreement and the safeguard clause, with the amendments we have presented, tries to make it easy, agile and provide guarantees.

We have presented amendments to protect European production in accordance with the Treaties and we establish safety mechanisms for both European production and production in the countries where the agreement is established.
The protection of the outermost regions is necessary because they are not diversified crops, due to the economic factor, because it affects a large number of
More than 10,000 direct jobs and 35,000 indirect jobs in Spain, in a population that has been heavily affected by unemployment and its specificity.
For example, the Canary Islands banana has a great specificity in agriculture, culture and gastronomy.

But it is also necessary where we are going to establish the agreement in Central America, Colombia and Peru, because trade is fundamental for development, and development is labor rights, sustainability and benefits for the producer.

Mr. President, the rapporteur's work is very good, but I would like to take this opportunity to say here, in this context, that our prose is very confusing, as anyone who approaches European legislation can see.
We forget what Pufendorf was already teaching, that general laws should be few and their meaning should be understood correctly.
Therefore, those who enact it must use all the clarity possible.
And Montesquieu always insisted that legal language must be precise and concise.
That is to say, we must avoid esoteric talk, full of neologisms and unjustified linguistic loans, because it generates a malicious network where traps nest and arbitrariness is established.
We deal with very complex issues in this Parliament, but it is our obligation to make them accessible to the citizens in a comprehensible and accessible way.
It is common that even legal professionals, judges and lawyers, are desperate in the face of our texts.
Dear colleagues, good prose is the courtesy of the legislator and a way to show respect for the citizen.
Mr. Deputy, I have just used the little time I had to insult and discredit from the utmost ignorance.
Ignorance. You know the Spanish Constitution.

Because what the Vice President, Mr. Vidal Cuadras, said is neither more nor less than that what is said in the Spanish Constitution is applied. The rest are singular personal appreciations that are absolutely out of place and that I can respect but disregard.

Mr. President, there is, ladies and gentlemen, an old principle that has been transferred from the legal to the political sphere, and that is pacta sunt servanda, that is, agreements are there to be fulfilled.
By this I refer to the important measures adopted by the European Council in June to solve the crisis that affects us.

Since the adoption of these agreements, the pressure from the markets has relaxed and they have positively received decisions that can break the vicious circle between banks and sovereign debt, as well as plans to move towards a genuine economic and monetary union and the commitment to defend the euro irreversibly.
The European Council held last week contains, ladies and gentlemen, undeniable positive aspects, and the conclusions of the progress towards the banking union are satisfactory.
The agreement of twenty-seven for the implementation of the banking supervisor is also positive. Finally, it is appropriate that the implementation is entrusted to the Eurozone's economy ministers.
But they will allow him to make a critical judgment with the biased interpretations that have been made of it unilaterally.

Honorable members, it is not acceptable to make particular interpretations that can distort the mandate granted to the ministers of Economy, nor do we applaud that matters that were not even discussed are described as agreements.
It is urgent to move towards a single supervisory mechanism that must cover all financial institutions.
A common deposit guarantee scheme and a crisis resolution mechanism are also needed.
The survival of the euro is linked to the urgent creation of an effective banking union.
Madam President, honourable Members, Commissioner, the advantages of the internal market are unquestionable: increase in competition, increase in the supply of products and services.
services, creation of new jobs, more affordable prices for consumers and greater protection, which are still not enough, and we cannot fall into complacency.
However, cultural, linguistic, protectionist and bureaucratic barriers prevent citizens and businesses from being able to fully take advantage of the benefits of the single market.
A year and a half ago we celebrated the presentation of the twelve priorities to stimulate growth and strengthen citizens'confidence in the internal market.
Unfortunately, no agreement has been reached on most of the proposals, as the Commission acknowledged in last week's communication.

Honorable members, Commissioner, the urgency of the crisis forces us to be ambitious, to go much further and to reach agreements as soon as possible to boost growth, employment and the confidence of citizens and businesses in the single market.
Mr. President, I also want to congratulate the rapporteur and the other colleagues who have worked very well on this reform.

The financial crisis has increased due to the existence of complex and strange tradable values that are linked to derivative instruments and trading outside of official markets, all with the aim of achieving high returns at high speed.
It is necessary to attract financial transactions to a transparent market to guarantee the good price formation and competition of tradable products.
But above all, it is essential that the information provided is understandable to investors, who must have full knowledge in order to give free consent to the risks they assume.
Transparency is of no use as a great glimmer of light if the mess in the configuration of negotiable products blinds the understanding of citizens.
I like Mrs. Thyssen's report because I believe that anything that strengthens the role and authority of this Parliament in the political debate is a step in the right direction.
Too often we hear accusations against European institutions for their poor democratic quality.
This is a statement made lightly, and this is not the time to enter into this debate.

Yes, to emphasize that this Parliament has the same legitimacy as any national Parliament, and it is even likely that, with regard to some, it will be governed by more transparent rules and, in addition, allow greater freedom for its members.
Therefore, all economic measures must pass the filter that this Parliament represents before their final approval and after examining their execution and results.
The group of experts designated to check in the States the fulfillment of the conditions imposed by the Community authorities and the representatives of the
The stability mechanism must appear in this House so that the Members of Parliament can have exhaustive and first-hand information.
Mr. President, five point three percent of the working population works in the automotive sector.
The numbers speak for themselves.
The decline in sales in the European market, combined with the business strategy, means that, in general, the outsourcing and restructuring of companies.
There is a crisis of overcapacity that currently affects ten assembly plants and potentially one hundred zero workers.
Unfortunately, there are few cases of restructuring with a long-term vision. Generally, a short-term vision prevails, in which the main element is to gain competitiveness based on labor adjustments.

I have to tell you that on the same day that Ford announced the suspension of the GEN plant, the Ford Valencia company was informed that its production was going to be moved to Germany, in the same business statement.

Therefore, we believe that it is a general problem in Europe, we believe that it is essential to create a legal framework at the European level that anticipates changes and underlines the importance of social dialogue.
Social dialogue is fundamental.
Mr. President, today we are discussing four reports that represent a revitalization of our common security and defense policy.
It is a clear sign of the conviction that our security and defense have a clear European dimension in the face of minority Eurosceptic sectors that also dominate in this House.
The report by Mr. Dan Jan, to whom I would like to thank for his spirit of seeking consensus during the preparation of the report, contains important contributions from the Socialist Group.
among others, references to effective multilateralism, the principle of the responsibility to protect or the concept of human security.
And we would like to see these aspects included in the possible revision of the European defense strategy.
We have also pointed out that a strong common security and defense policy is also of interest to our transatlantic alliance.
I must highlight another challenge that is taking on important dimensions for our global security.
It is the report on cybersecurity and cyber defense that we also discussed today and whose suggestions we hope will be included in the new European cybersecurity strategy.
In a context of severe economic and financial crisis, in which the member states are forced to cut their defense budgets, European projects are most needed.
That is why it is more important than ever to strengthen the role of the European Defence Agency, which is being heavily contested today.
I conclude by stating that we can relaunch European security and defense and do so with President Van Rompuy's project for the Council in December 2013.
Many thanks to the four rapporteurs.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, once again the defense of the general interests defended by the Commission and the Parliament clashes with national egoisms that camp in the Council.
From the previous acceptance of the legitimacy of both positions, it is inexcusable to achieve a balance.
The relevance of the next financial framework is unquestionable.
The Spanish delegation of the EPP and I, on their behalf, reiterate that the Presidency's proposal is, in our opinion, unacceptable.
A cut of seventy-five zero million euros on the already inevitably scarce proposal of the European Commission is sterile and useless.
And that's not all, the new direct cut to agricultural and cohesion policies means crossing the red line that Spain has pointed out since the beginning of the work.
Honorable members, it is no longer time to discuss a supposed dichotomy between austerity and growth.
Some of us are making proven efforts and sacrifices to correct the deficit.
But Spain, like many other countries, needs to grow, increase economic activity and create jobs.
And with this budget, we are not getting anywhere. On the contrary, it constitutes a missile in the floating line.
Honorable members, it is not possible to achieve more Europe with much fewer resources, especially if what we have is distributed unfairly.

If that is the case, Spain will oppose a financial framework for the European Union that simply means the disappearance of growth possibilities and, above all, any vestige of solidarity, and this is precisely the direction the European Council is taking.
Fortunately, this is not the path that the Commission points out, and we must thank them for their efforts to point out a different route.

And at this point, in the need for union, in the need for shared efforts, I would like to thank Mr. Barroso for making a strong statement the other day in Cádiz on the interpretation of the Treaties for a supposed secessionist within the Union.

He made it clear, unequivocally, as guardian of the Treaties, that if a part of a member state separates as an independent state, it becomes considered a third country and, therefore, the declarations and effects of the Treaty itself will not affect it in any way.

I hope, Mr. Vice President, in the absence of the President, that this can be taken up and that this safe and constant doctrine of the Commission can continue to remain alive for the guarantee of all.
